PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;

that we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life;
that we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 190 citizens) and Messner (from 35 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate.
The petition of the undersigned do respectfully showeth that pornographic material relating to children is deleterious to the health and welfare of children and society as a whole.
We respectfully urge the Government to ban all child pornography from entering or from being produced in Australia.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 315 citizens), Crichton-Browne (from 54 citizens) and Jones (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. 2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled should be aware that a significant number of Australians:

strongly protest that the Department of Social Security pays married rate benefits to persons who are under the age of consent and living in a de-facto relationship involving the crimes of defilement and unlawful carnal knowledge, and strongly protest the 1985 decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which effectively encourages young people to leave home, establish a de-facto relationship, and then be paid $202.30 a week for their activities.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island Preservation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Moreton Island is an invaluable natural resource for Queensland and the world and that mining on Moreton would gravely compromise its unique flora and fauna and its outstanding recreational archaeological and scientific values.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
urge the government to use its proven constitutional powers to halt sand mining on Moreton by supporting the Moreton Island Preservation Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: How to Vote Cards

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

millions of dollars of taxpayers money is spent at each Federal election in Australia in the drafting, production and distribution of How-to-Vote cards which are unnecessary and pollutant and that this waste is not desirable or essential in assisting the electorate to vote informatively for their parliamentarians.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

urge the government to introduce legislation which requires that the registered How-to-Vote cards of all political parties and candidates for political office must be placed under glass in every polling booth within obvious sight of all voters, thus making it unnecessary for How-to-Vote cards to be distributed at future federal elections.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the threat to personal freedom posed by the introduction of the Australia Card, call on the Government to withdraw the enabling legislation on the following grounds:
1. Expert opinion does not agree ``that a National identification system for all Australians'' would ``combat tax evasion and welfare fraud''.

3. The potential for the invasion of individual privacy by persons unknown to the private citizen is so great as to be unacceptable to us.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

the Hawke Labor Government's Australia Card proposal is the most far-reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever and on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
reject the Labor Government's Australia Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's `Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureau-cracy of 2,000 public servants within the Health Insu-rance Commission (HIC), with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identities, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.'' (Report, 4.55, page 148).

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Go-vernment now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the members of the Senate without regard for party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned, would like to voice our protest at the proposed legislation for the Australia Card. This petition of Australian citizens shows:
1. We reject in principle the need for a national I.D. card on the basis that it will be a gross violation of civil liberties and personal freedoms.

2. We support proper measures by government to stamp out tax avoidance. We equally believe that the introduction of a national system of identification and sensitive data storage is a massive intrusion into the privacy of those least likely to be involved in tax avoidance practices, and equally less likely to be effective against those who are.

3. We reject the notion that the government, on the basis of its recent re-election, can claim a mandate for the proposed legislation. The Australia Card was not a debated pre-election policy issue and we categorically state that it does not reflect our will.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this legislation.

STATEMENT IN RESPECT OF POLICE ADVICE TO THE DEPARTMENTS AND MINISTERS FOR TRANSPORT, AND TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS, IN RELATION TO THE SUITABILITY OF AMANN AVIATION TO HOLD THE COASTWATCH CONTRACT

1 Prior to the award of the contract (13 March 1987), security checks were carried out by the Australian Federal Police. Chief Superintendent Dixon interrogated AFP and State police records and sought comments from the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. No adverse findings were recorded. Chief Superintendent Dixon reported orally to the Tender Assessment Committee on 21 January 1987;
- the relevant extract from the record of that meeting is at Annexure 1.
2 The AFP confirmed with the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission that no adverse matter was recorded in relation to the tenderer prior to the award of the contract.

3 The AFP carried out over a period of several months checks of Mr Joseph Shlegeris, an employee of Continental Venture Capital Ltd who became a director of Amann Aviation Pty Ltd. As Mr Shlegeris was an American, these checks necessarily involved contact with United States law enforcement agencies through AFP Liaison Officers in the USA. Mr Shlegeris was not adversely recorded in either the United States or Australia. These findings were the subject of oral report by Chief Superintendent Dixon and there does not appear to be any material retained on Departmental files.

4 After the contract was let but before the end of May, the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence within the AFP raised concerns in an undated internal minute about some of the associates of some of the Directors of Continental Venture Capital Ltd and concluded ``there is sufficient justification in continuing a probe into Amann Aviation and its associated links''. This conclusion and the fact of these further investigations were not then drawn to the attention of the Department or Ministers as they were of a speculative and preliminary nature.
5 The Bureau of Criminal Intelligence reported to the Coastal Protection Unit (CPU) and the Deputy Commissioner (Operations) of the AFP on 30 June 1987.
6 It would be inappropriate to table or quote from that document because:
- it contains details of the private affairs of a number of persons including their credit and other financial dealings;

- it contains speculation about persons being involved in illegal activities which have not been the subject of full investigation or charges and the disclosure of which would be very damaging to the persons concerned;
- it could prejudice criminal investigations in relation to matters unrelated to the subject contract and the principals involved in it.

7 This report and other matters were reviewed by Chief Superintendent Dixon in an internal note for file on 16 July 1987 (Annexure 2). Neither that document nor its contents were drawn to the attention of the Department or of Ministers at that time.

8 Chief Superintendent Dixon's conclusions that there was no reason to ``(a) pursue this probe further or (b) initiate actions to alert any other persons/Department of the initial BCI'' report were agreed by the Deputy Commissioner. The investigation ceased.

9 On 31 August 1987 allegations connecting Mr Amann with the use and/or smuggling of drugs were made to the AFP. The conclusions and recommendations of the relevant internal AFP minute are reproduced as Annexure 3. Investigations were put in train by the AFP and the Australian Customs Service. No adverse findings have been reported arising from these investigations.

10 On 1 September Chief Superintendent Dixon drew these matters to the notice of Mr Roger Beale, Associate Secretary, of the Department of Transport and Communications and briefed him on the earlier inquiries by the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and the conclusions of AFP in relation to those inquiries.

11 Mr Roger Beale drew these matters, and the AFP's conclusions, to the attention of Senator Evans, the Minister for Transport and Communications in the context of a minute on 1 September. The relevant extract is reproduced at Annexure 4 with appropriate excisions to protect the identities of persons referred to in the BCI report and persons providing information to the AFP.
12 Mr R. Beale further discussed these matters with Deputy Commissioner Farmer on 4 September 1987. A copy of his note for file is reproduced as Annexure 5.
13 Mr Beale briefed Senator Evans on these matters in Melbourne on 7 September and it was agreed that they were not such as to justify any action to terminate the contract.
14 Between 7 September and the notice of termination on 12 September, no further information or advice was provided by the AFP.

1. In discussion with Robert Amann (Darwin-9.7.87) he provided me with the following information:

(2) CVC has no control of the contract/operations of Amann Aviation except in circumstances where Amann was in default of repayments over $.5m. 5. The matter has been discussed with Superintendent Ray PHILLIPS, NSW Region 13/11. We are of the view that (1) any matters of specific concern in BCI should be clarified by direct approach to Amann or SCHLEGERIS. These should be identified by BCI, having regard to the delicacy and availability of their intelligence. (2) That the situation of CVC appears no different from that which exists in other companies and that in depth investigations into any major company would be likely to disclose people subject of BCI record. (3) There is nothing, apparently, of substance to indicate untoward interest or involvement in Amann by CVC or that CVC is other than it represents itself to be-a management and investment company of good repute.
6. Comment:
(1) I have no reason to doubt the integrity of Mr Amann or the bona fides of the company with which he is financially involved (CVC).

(2) Mr Amann has been quite frank in his discussions with me (and in contact with Department of Transport officers). He displays a willingness to answer queries or identify problems in regard to him, his company and the establishment of the contract operations.

(3) The information provided by the BCI while of interest is neither specific in fact or implicit in its conclusions (this is not a criticism of the BCI). In any event CVC have no control of the contract or the operations Amann Aviation undertakes on behalf of COASTWATCH.

(4) It is often forgotten (or not understood) that littoral contracts are not designed for or intended to encompass drug interdiction. Accordingly access to information about littoral programs/schedules would not provide any would-be trafficker with information he could not obtain through a knowledge of northern Australia.

(5) The matter in issue is the possible embarrassment to the Government if the CVC Directors or corporate associates are disclosed to be of ill repute or with organised crime connotations. This has not been established, nor do I believe on information available to me that an initial suspicion of such connections can be substantiated.

(6) Accordingly I am of the view that unless some significant matter can be identified by the BCI as of concern to them or with implications for the Government and/or the civil coastal surveillance system I see no reason to (a) pursue this probe further or (b) initiate actions to alert any other persons/Department of the initial BCI report.

I can assure honourable senators that the advice of the AFP was considered closely by my senior officers and myself. TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia oppose the Australia Card Bill 1986 (No. 3) root and branch. We oppose it from clause 1 to clause 189, from page 1 to page 130. We oppose every element of this Bill which encroaches upon and reduces the rights and freedoms of all Australians. We oppose this Bill which redefines Australian men, women and children as `card subjects' and puts us all under an authority with a capital `A'. We will do all that we can to ensure that this Bill is exposed for the sham and the fraud that it is and we will use every proper, normal parliamentary device at our disposal to defeat it consistent with our manifest obligations to the majority of Australian electors who, at the last election, voted for parties pledged to oppose the Australia Card. In the event that this measure eventually becomes law, I assure the people of Australia that we will repeal the legislation lock, stock and barrel.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn first to an analysis of the second reading speech on this Bill given yesterday by the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan. It was as dishonest and dishonourable a speech as any government has produced. It was a speech which sought to deceive and to dissemble as this Government seeks to move us towards its vision of a totalitarian state full of bureaucratic pimps, spies and regulators. I turn therefore to look at exactly what the Minister said in her second reading speech. She said of this device that it was the best single instrument available to ensure fairness and equity in the tax and welfare system. That is untrue. The best single instrument available is lower taxation, which people regard as fair and proper. The lie is further given to the Minister's assertion by this morning's Australian Financial Review, which contains an interview with the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, which states in part:
Mr Boucher however admitted there was no `single formula' to successfully reducing tax evasion and avoidance.

The Minister in her speech says that the Australia Card program has a limited and specific purpose. We know that that is not true. The other day in Brisbane the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, said that he wanted the extension of this scheme to cover Veterans' Affairs. He said:
Most of the veterans already have all their records on file anyway, and it would make little difference to take it one step further.

It is this one step further with which the Opposition parties and the people of Australia are concerned. We know that the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), by its own admission, wants to move one step at a time. In its outline plan it stated:

It will be important to minimise any adverse public reaction to implementation of the system. One possibility would be to use a staged approach for implementation, whereby only less sensitive data are held in the system initially, with the facility to input additional data at a later stage when public acceptance may be forthcoming more readily.

So the Minister is simply not correct when she says that the program will have a limited and specific purpose. She stated in her speech that this card will provide a method of ensuring that there are no hassles when dealing with Social Security officers. Why is it then that the Department of Social Security told the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card that it would not accept the Australia Card on its own as being proof of identity for social security purposes? That is simply not true.

She talked about the extent to which it will minimise the need for most Australians to use more than one Australian government card. You will notice, Madam Acting Deputy President, that it has suddenly become a government card. It has suddenly become part of a government system, because it is the Government and the bureaucrats in the Government, who are the beneficiaries. The legislation refers to card subjects. According to this legislation we are not allowed to talk about Australian citizens. We do not talk about individuals; we talk about card subjects. We have been redefined by this Government as card subjects. The Minister, in her speech, stated that people will not need to use it very often except in their Medicare dealings. That is simply untrue. For instance, anybody who participates in casual employment, every baby-sitter, every gardener, every house cleaner or casual ironing lady, every primary producer-as Senator Panizza has pointed out to me-who seeks to undertake transactions which are derived from the partnership nature of this rural involvement, will need to produce this card for all of the transactions that they undertake for the delivery of their grain, for the purchase of their fuel, for their casual employment.

In the next paragraph of the Minister's speech is the first reference-the sneaking reference-to what this is all about. She states that the program will be basic and simple by linking all sources of a person's income to that number. Linking is precisely what this legislation is about. It is about linking records. It is about linking all of the information currently collected for discrete purposes and held in discrete files by separate and different departments. She then talks about the savings over a 10-year period, and the revenue yield of $5.4 billion. That, of course, is based upon the presumption that in the course of the next 10 years there will be no reduction in the levels of taxation, because if taxation comes down, as it should, revenue will go down in terms of this device. We are supposed to accept from the Government that there will be no reduction in revenue brought about by a reduction in taxation, which is necessary, and that there will be increases in costs to which this Government will not admit. For instance, the Joint Select Committee found evidence that this Government had provided not one brass razoo for increases in computer equipment in the next 10 years.

Is there anybody in this place-anybody in this country-who thinks that the Government will be able to run a system of this size, of this dimension, of this sophistication, without providing a single dollar for upgrading and improving computer equipment over a 10-year period? That is the sort of nonsense this Government comes forward with. When we take this Bill to a Senate committee we will be able to expose clearly, as the committee chaired by Senator Aulich exposed clearly, the bogus nature of the Government's financial claims as far as this matter is concerned.

The Minister says in her speech that few people in Australian society would not already be attached to one or more numbered identification systems. That is true. The issue is, however: are they all linked? The answer to that is no, nor should they be, nor will they be when the Australia Card is eventually defeated. The Minister goes on to say that this information will be held discretely and separately, that tax information will stay with the Australian Taxation Office, that social security records will stay with the Department of Social Security, and that Medicare information will remain separate and secure. What she ought to have added at the end of that, however, is that Health Insurance Commission data will remain with the Australian Federal Police, with the Sunday newspapers or with whomever the bureaucrats in the HIC decide to give it to in the sorts of sleazy political activities in which they have regularly indulged themselves whenever they have been on their doctor bashing exercise or whenever it has suited the political demands of their government masters of the day.

While at the moment the police in their jackboots are storming through the HIC looking for the people who have been releasing information to the Australian Privacy Foundation, not one person has been brought to account for the leaking of information, a practice which the HIC regularly indulges in for purely sleazy political purposes. We are told by the Minister that there will be limited information on the Register. The missing word is `now'. It may be limited now, but we know what Mr Humphreys has in mind, we know what his Government has in mind and we know that that first step is the step which has to be resisted.

The Minister says that the great bulk of Western democratic societies have some form of basic identification system. That is not true. The great bulk of countries which have identification systems are, as I have pointed out consistently, those whose systems of government and law work upon a civil law basis, rather than a common law basis, in which there lies the presumption of guilt-not the presumption of innocence-and in which the whole method of collecting and storing data about individuals is entrenched. The great common law countries, the great Western democracies whose systems of government and law are based upon common law principles-be they Great Britain, the United States, Canada or New Zealand-have consistently rejected, for good and proper reasons, the sort of system which this Government wishes to introduce.

We are told that the Australia Card program will use dedicated landlines, not telephone lines, thus denying access to computer hackers. Yet the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), on the last occasion that he was asked about this, could not give us any information. In the other place his junior, Mr Duncan, could not give us any information. After the fiasco about Amann Aviation Pty Ltd it is no wonder. Ministers have to go out and talk to each other in King's Hall to get their collective stories straight before they come into the chamber and start answering questions. The Minister's assurance about the security of the system was given the lie yesterday by her own Press statement. Headed `Ryan denies ``Secret'' Dossier', it says, in part:
None of the charts or diagrams produced give any guide to the eventual operation of the Card computer programs which have not yet been finalised.

So the Government comes in here with a piece of legislation to set up a system, which it admits is not yet finalised, and says that it will be secure, despite the fact that it is not yet finalised. How can the Government give us that sort of assurance when, in the Minister's own Press statement, she says clearly that it has not even been worked out how the computer system is going to operate?

The Bill supposedly establishes a Data Protection Agency. We know, despite the attempts of the then Minister, Senator Grimes, to mislead us about the circumstances of Mr Jan Freese's resignation from the Swedish Data Protection Board, that he resigned because the model which has been used by this Government for data protection has already been found to be a defective model. We are told that the Data Protection Agency will have powers equivalent to those of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. We know, from Senator Walsh's behaviour regarding the investigation of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of the Industrial Sugar Mills case, that when it suits the Minister to ignore the Ombudsman's recommendations he ignores them and that consequently this as a protection is absolutely valueless.
We are told that it will be a serious offence under the legislation for people to demand the production of the card. That is not correct. Clause 167 of the Bill states:
Except as authorised by this Act, a person shall not require another person to produce a Card.

It will not be an offence for a policeman or a publican to ask a person; it will be an offence if they require a person to produce the card. However, if they ask a person to produce it and he cannot do so, what is the remedy? The answer is none. This Government has to come clean on this. If a publican can say, `I am sorry, but if you cannot prove that you are over the legal age to drink I will not serve you', and a policeman can say, `If you cannot prove who you are I will take the sort of action against you that I think I am entitled to take; prove it by showing me your Australia Card', the Government is simply dishonest in saying that there is adequate protection.
The Minister's second reading speech states:
The Bill does not place any legal obligation on a person to produce a card in relation to employment.

Of course it does not. It imposes a substantial financial penalty. What a nice form of weasel words these are: `does not place any legal obligation'. It means simply that a person will pay through the nose unless he produces the card. The financial penalty exists and this Government cannot weasel out of it by saying that there is no legal obligation on a person to produce a card. Senator Gareth Evans undoubtedly would be pleased to hear that, according to a news- paper report today, his colleague in another place, Mr Duncan, was asked whether it was physically possible to tap into the system, and he said, `Yes'. So once again Senator Evans and Mr Duncan are clearly at odds with each other. The trouble with members of the left faction of the Australian Labor Party, as you would know, Madam Acting Deputy President, is that they have a propensity to tell the truth. The information given by Mr Duncan on this occasion is yet another example of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the full text.

—I am sorry if Senator Evans finds it offensive for people to say that members of the left faction of his Party tell the truth and he has difficulty recognising it. I turn briefly to the three primary claims that the Government makes about the value and importance of the card-that it will do something about, firstly, tax avoidance; secondly, welfare fraud; and thirdly, illegal migration. The first claim is simply untrue. We know, from the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled A taxing problem-a review of efficiency audit reports into the Australian Taxation Office, that a large number of things can be done and must be done within the Taxation Office to improve the efficiency of the existing system. We know, for heaven's sake, that the Taxation Office is one organisation which manages to underspend the money which the Parliament gives it for its computer equipment. For instance, in 1982-83 the Parliament appropriated $14.8m and the ATO spent $10.4m. In 1983-84 we appropriated $28m and it spent $9m. In 1984-85 we appropriated $21m and it spent $10.9m. We know that there are better ways within the tax system to improve its efficiency. As strange as it may seem to honourable senators opposite, I repeat the point that the Government will get more tax revenue and better compliance with the tax laws when it brings taxes down to a fair and equitable level and spends the money which it raises from taxation in a way which the people of Australia think is fair and proper and so do not mind making their proper contributions. We know that this system will not do anything, under any circumstances, to police the cash economy. We know that every country in Europe that operates with a type of identity card system, operates with a massive cash economy. We know that up to 20 per cent of the total economic activity of Sweden, because of high taxes and the card-type system, operates within the black economy. We know that in Italy, for example, probably half-if not more-of the economic activity takes place within the cash economy. We know full well that this card will have no effect upon that except to inconvenience a large number of ordinary Australians who are going about their proper, legitimate, day-by-day economic and social activities.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that this system will not work in terms of welfare fraud. The Department of Social Security has not only said that it will not accept the card as evidence on its own of the identity of persons; it also came before the Joint Select Committee and made a compelling case as to why it did not want the system introduced in the first place. When Senator Chaney was the Minister for Social Security, and before him, when former Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was the Minister, this matter was looked at consistently by the Department of Social Security and rejected as an ineffective method of policing the welfare system.

We know that it will not work in terms of the problems of migrants and illegal migration in this country. All it will do is ensure that prohibited non-citizens who are here and who are working are subjected to even greater exploitation than they are subjected to at the moment. If one looks at the report of the Joint Select Committee, one will see that the evidence given by the then Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr McKinnon, was the most woeful evidence ever given to a joint select committee. We were told in his evidence that the figures that were given to us were `presumed figures'. They are Mr McKinnon's words. They were `rough estimates'. They are Mr McKinnon's words. They were `no more than guesswork'. They are Mr McKinnon's words. He went on to say that if they redid the study which they had done some five years ago-and I quote:
We probably could not find the same crystal ball that was then used.
I asked him:
Would you say basically that it is still a crystal ball type of calculation, Mr McKinnon?
He replied:
Yes. I do not think any of us are going to claim any great precision.

In respect of immigration, we have the Secretary to the Department coming before us with his presumptions, his guesswork, his guesstimates and his crystal ball, and he still cannot tell us anything that is actually of any value.

I have already mentioned the extent to which we know that in a financial sense this whole proposition is a nonsense. It is a nonsense in terms of revenue, it is a nonsense in terms of grossly understating the costs. I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that this Government has consistently refused to give its estimates of the cost of this system to this Parliament, to either State governments or local government or to the private sector. The banks say clearly that there may be several hundred million dollars of cost to them-so much so that on 8 September the Minister put out a statement authorising the resumption of discussions with the Australian Bankers Association on implementation of the Australia Card program. How can the Government then come to us and say that this will be the cost of running the system when it is now re-authorising negotiations to try to work out how much the wretched system is going to cost?

I come to the question of privacy and civil liberties. I know that this Government is not particularly concerned about civil liberties and about privacy. I know that it is perfectly happy to have a system by which it describes the people of Australia not only as `card subjects' but also, through its own planning documents, describes the people as `entities entitled to operate'. This is what this Government thinks of the status of privacy and of the rights of individuals. They are card subjects. They are subject to the `Authority', and the Bill describes the Authority with a capital A. They are card subjects or entities entitled to operate. That is the sort of attitude which this Government takes towards the people of Australia.

We come to the question of organised crime. We know Commissioner Costigan has stated in the clearest possible terms his belief that this system should not be introduced and will not make any significant impact on organised crime. The Hansard of the Committee's proceedings of 6 February is taken entirely with the testimony of Mr Costigan and Mr Meagher making this point at considerable length. We know that the Australian Federal Police indicated that they did not believe the system would, in any way, be effective. We know that in the United States of America the Presidential Commission, the Comptroller-General, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the inquiry into the use of false identities all recommended against the introduction of such a card. We know full well that a top crime fighter in New South Wales, former Inspector Merv Beck, makes this perfectly clear. There is a recent newspaper article headed `Beck says crime will be Identification winner'. It states:
Mr Merv Beck, the former New South Wales policeman known for his zeal in closing Sydney's illegal casinos, believes the Australia Card could pave the way for corporate crime `on a massive scale'.
There is no way that Government could police the thousands of public servants with access to people's private records from stealing or selling information to those organised crime groups.

We know that organised crime would be delighted to have this system in place. We know that Dr Blewett has admitted in the House of Representatives that it would not be easy to detect fake cards or forged cards. We know, in fact, that a senior officer of the Commission for the Future-one of this Government's particular playthings of the moment-has denounced this card proposal as a massive intrusion into civil liberties and personal privacy. Senator Archer showed, when he put out a statement in January this year dealing with the case of a bagman for a major organised crime syndicate, Frank Duggan, that there was absolutely no way in which security of cards could be policed.

I have got a card made up like the Australia Card. Undoubtedly, a large number of members of Parliament have received these cards. I have got about half a dozen that have the delightful visage of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) upon them. People tell me that these cards will not be susceptible to forgery or to being misused.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't you like to have one?

—No, I would not like to have one with the Prime Minister's photograph on it because if I showed it to any self-respecting pub I would very properly get thrown out. We know full well the attitude which this Government takes towards the civil rights and liberties of people in this country; we know how tardy it has been in policing civil liberties, in policing leaks from the Department of Social Security, from the Health Insurance Commission and from various other Government instrumentalities.

SPEECH.PARA: It is one of the great obscenities of this debate for the term `Australia' to be so prostituted, as it is, by being linked to this card system. The Government should at least be honest enough to call it a compulsory national identity card. The Government should not indulge in the prostitution of the name `Australia' to give the card some respectability, should not link the green and gold colours with the card to try to conceal from the people of Australia not that it is doing something which is fundamentally Australian but that it is doing something which is fundamentally un-Australian. It is fundamentally contrary to everything that this country has represented and has stood for; it is contrary to the principles which the Labor Party once espoused, that Prime Ministers such as Curtin, Chifley and Forde made clear in their comments that they would have no bar of. As soon as the national emergency of the war was over, the first thing that those Labor governments wanted to do was to get rid of national identification systems-of numbering, of cards, of records and all the rest of it. It takes Hawke, Keating and Senator Ryan to think once again about a system of renumbering the people of Australia, as I said the other day, as this Government's bicentenary present to the nation.

We know the attitude taken by this Government towards the privacy of individuals. We know that Dr Blewett says, `Don't get hung up about it because, after all, it is only a bourgeois right associated with the right to private property'. The right to private property has never been something that Mr Keating has walked away from in the past. I doubt whether it is something that he will walk away from in the future. On behalf of this Opposition I say this: We have analysed this proposal very carefully and, had it been possible to devise a system which effectively policed the tax, welfare and migration systems at reasonable cost and without interfering with the rights and liberties of the people of Australia, we would have been prepared to support it. We are not prepared to support this scheme. In fact, we want this matter further investigated.

I will now formally move the second reading amendment which has been circulated in the chamber and which seeks the reference of this proposal to a Senate committee and lays down the terms of reference for such a committee. I move:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert:
``, whereas:
[Preamble]

(a) while the Senate has received a report of a committee on the proposed identity card, the committee did not have the benefit of examining the Government's proposed legislation, as its reference was limited to consideration of the concept and not the Bill;
(b) further, the committee was a joint select committee and not a Senate committee;
(c) the Bill presented by the Government is particularly complex, being both very technical and lengthy and thus requiring close scrutiny;

(d) recent public statements made by several Ministers and the Government's responses to the relevant Scrutiny of Bills Committee report have revealed the necessity to make amendments to the legislation;

(e) the Minister responsible for the legislation, Senator Ryan, has, since the election, been reported as acknowledging the need to consult with civil liberties organisations on measures to strengthen privacy safeguards;
(f) one of the Government's responses to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report was unsatisfactory and requires further consideration;

(g) the Government stressed the significance of the Bill in seeking the recent double dissolution and accordingly the legislation should be the subject of thorough and careful examination by the Senate through a select committee; and
(h) there have arisen changed circumstances since the matter was last considered by the Senate, and in particular:
(i) heightened concern in the community that the issues have been inadequately debated in the parliament and the community,
(ii) the election of a number of new Senators (thus reflecting current feeling in the electorate) who did not have the opportunity to participate in the previous committee,
(iii) the inability of the previous committee, due to the legislation not being drafted, to obtain a full assessment of the costs to business of compliance with the proposal, and
(iv) the possible failure of some State or Territory governments to cooperate in vital aspects of the proposed system,
this Bill be referred to a select committee, the powers and composition of which be contained in a subsequent resolution, and the committee:
[Terms of reference]
(a) examine in detail the provisions of the Bill;
(b) consider the provisions of the Bill in the light of the reports of the Joint Select Committee on the Australia Card and of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee;
(c) examine the integrity of the card manufacturing process in order to assess the likelihood of forgery and fraudulent or criminal misuse;
(d) assess the feasibility of the proposed system in the event of a failure of any one or more States to cooperate in the establishment of a births, deaths and marriages register;
(e) examine the extent to which new or updated computer systems and recent crackdown campaigns on welfare cheating and tax avoidance and evasion will obviate the need for the proposed system;
(f) assess the costs to the private sector of the introduction of the proposed system;

(g) determine the capacity of the proposed Data Protection Agency to adequately safeguard and protect the privacy of the individual and to control unauthorised use of the card and/or individual identification numbers by commercial organisations such as credit insurance companies and unincorporated associations and clubs;

(h) investigate the desirability, timing and nature of comprehensive privacy legislation in Australia and the extent to which it might or should replace the privacy protection arrangements proposed in relation to the Australia Card;
(i) examine the extent to which the proposed system accords with OECD guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data (1981);
(j) consider the appropriateness of the range and level of proposed penalties on individuals and other entities;
(k) determine whether any, and if so what, limits or penalties should attach to unauthorised use of identification numbers by Federal, State and local government agencies and private sector bodies;
(l) take evidence from overseas experts as to the experience of other countries with analogous identity card systems; and
(m) present a final report on or before the first day of sitting in 1988.

We reject the Australia Card. We reject this Government's Orwellian future, this nightmare of a brave new world of Hawkespeak in which all are numbered and all numbers are linked; in which all need to prove themselves to the Government; in which we become entities entitled to operate; in which the basis of our society, with a government as servant and the people as masters, is reversed; in which all Australians become card subjects; and in which `authority' is now spelt with a capital `A'. This obscenely named Australia Card is so un-Australian that it will be rejected, reviled and, if necessary, repealed by us as it will be rejected and reviled by every decent, freedom loving, honest and law abiding Australian man, woman and child.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always good to start the day with a bit of entertainment, and Senator Puplick, as usual, has been quite Shakespearian in his approach. Unfortunately, of course, what he is really doing is representing the sort of approach that has been taken by a number of people who have opposed the Australia Card over the last year or so. Unfortunately, he is also now in the forefront of--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, is it not interesting? When the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) got up to speak about one of the major issues confronting this Parliament over the last year she was brayed at, abused and treated in a way that I regard as most unparliamentary. I get up to speak-as only the second Government speaker-and a similar approach is taken by people who stand up today and describe themselves as defenders of civil liberties and the right of people to speak and to have their voices heard. Yet in this Parliament one has to raise one's voice-to shout-to be heard. Are these two aspects of their approach somewhat at odds? Surely honourable senators opposite could give Government speakers the opportunity or the right to be heard in this chamber without their braying like donkeys from the other side of it. They are supposed to be-or they are at least disguising themselves as-the defenders of civil liberties.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk about that particular issue to begin with. As I said, the approach Senator Puplick is taking is representative of the approach that has been taken by a number of people on this issue-this unusual coalition that has raised itself in the last three of four weeks to oppose the Australia Card. I suppose that the best way to start is to look at this pamphlet that has been put out by an organisation called the Australian Privacy Foundation in its national campaign against the identification card. Of course it is in black, and it says: `Why the Identification card must be stopped now'. I will quote from some of the people whose photographs appear in this pamphlet and who are prepared to make comments about Australia's future should an Australia Card be introduced. Let us hear what Ben Lexcen, the yacht designer, said:
The Australia Card is an obscenity. It will destroy this country. If the government is allowed to get away with introducing it, I will turn in my citizenship and leave Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has already changed his name.

—Apart from changing his name, apparently he now intends to change his citizenship because his views are not reflected in this Parliament. Let us take the words of Dr Bruce Shepherd, another great defender of civil liberties in this country, and the President-elect of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Medical Association:

SPEECH.PARA: I am appalled at the prospect of my country being under such awful control. It's going to turn Australian against Australian. But given the horrific impact the card will have on Australia, its defeat would almost be worth-
and listen to this-
fighting a civil war for.

They are just two quotations from two supposedly eminent opponents of the Australia Card. That is the nature of the debate that has been created by the card's opponents around this country, specifically over the last three or four weeks, despite the fact that we have already fought an election on that issue, an election which saw this Government returned comfort- ably to this Parliament and with a mandate to introduce the Australia Card.

It is not interesting? Senator Puplick had his say. We listened without interjection to his views on the Australia Card. Senator Stone has left. Senator Puplick has left. There are two Liberal members in the chamber for a Bill that they regard as being horrendous and to which they are totally opposed in all sorts of ways on all sorts of grounds. Where is their interest in this issue? I am amazed. There were two Liberals and now there is one. (Quorum formed) As I said, I am fascinated. This is the most important Bill that the Liberals and Nationals intend to oppose and they can muster only two members in the chamber. These are the people who talk about someone's right to free speech, the right to be heard, and the community's rights to have its viewpoints heard in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many of your colleagues were in here when you started?

—The honourable senator's voice could bring down aeroplanes from the sky, so she should just sit quietly and listen. The interesting thing is that these are the people who, during the election campaign, when we raised the issue of the Australia Card, refused to debate it. They refused to come to the party. As someone said: it takes two to tango. One can get an election issue going only if both parties are prepared to make a public issue of it and debate it. We raised this matter very early in the piece. The very first advertisement in the campaign was about the need to bring in the Australia Card as soon as possible. What did the Liberals do at the time? They did nothing. They ran away from the issue. I am not the only one that believes that. Let us look at what some of the respected journalists in this Parliament have said. The Australian Financial Review noted in a report on Thursday, 20 August:

SPEECH.PARA: According to Liberal sources, the Opposition did not campaign strongly against the ID Cards in the last election, mainly because market research showed 64 per cent of the electorate were in favour of the cards and it was judged too difficult to turn around during the election . . .
That is an estimate of what the Liberals were about at the time. I quote Mike Steketee:

For emotional claptrap, it is hard to go past the present debate on an identity card. There has seldom been a subject on which there has been so much misunderstanding, so much misrepresentation, and so much downright irrational fear.

My three criticisms are, first, that the Liberals simply did not want to debate this matter during the election campaign; secondly, that they are simply not game to come into this chamber and hear what the Government has to say about the Australia Card; and, thirdly, that they are simply working on irrational fears and emotions in the community in order to oppose this card. Senator Puplick has shown just what sort of approach the Liberals are taking. In his speech he used such words-I did not bother to get up and take a point of order on him for using unparliamentary language-as `lies', `jackboots', `storm troopers' and `weasels'. Is that the way to debate a major issue that will affect this country over the next 10 years in one of its major debating chambers? Alternatively, is that the approach members of the Opposition take out in the community at large so that they need not attend this forum? What do Opposition members do? Do they use emotional claptrap to deal with the issue, as Senator Puplick tried to do, or do they simply stay out of the chamber, as the Liberals and Nationals are doing at the moment?

Let us go to another example of emotional claptrap-Why the ID Card Must be Stopped Now! Let us look at some of the misrepresentation that has occurred in the pamphlets that have been sent out on the part of people who oppose the card. Under a section headed `Why do we need it?' it is stated:

The parliamentary committee that was set up to investigate the Australia Card plan recommended AGAINST any form of card system. The committee slammed the proposal, calling it wasteful, pointless and dangerous.
After hearing evidence from a wide range of experts, the committee recommended `a tax file number' system that would be cheaper, safer and more effective.

The distinct impression given in this brochure is that somehow or other the whole Committee was opposed to the Australia Card, that the whole Committee described it as horrendous, that the whole Committee recommended the tax file number system as the appropriate way to go. What this brochure, and many others like it, did not say was that the Committee was split; that the Australian Labor Party gave its members a free vote in essence but that the Liberals forced all of their members to vote in accord with their Party decision; that the Liberals in fact turned around the position of a National Party person on that committee, Mr Blunt. His original support for the Australia Card diminished overnight as he was instructed by his Party Leader and by the Liberal Party to go out and oppose the Australia Card. There is nothing in this brochure to indicate that that happened, that in fact there was a split.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the second time that Mr Blunt has been named as the fourth man.

—Exactly, the fourth man. Not only was he the fourth man; he was the missing man when it came to a showing of hands in favor of the ordinary people in this community who are going to be protected by the Australia Card.

SPEECH.PARA: What the brochure also does not say is that the supposed alternative of the tax file number system, supposedly recommended by the majority of the Committee or, as the brochure put it, the whole Committee, was dropped as an alternative proposal to the Australia Card less than eight weeks after the Committee's report came out.

How consistent and sincere is the Opposition been about this issue? It is all very well for those opposite to put out documents such as this with all their emotional claptrap and to come into this chamber and bray at every Government speaker, disrupt the speech of the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) and make a mockery of this Parliament, but when it is time to stand up to be counted and to be consistent, they are simply not there. As far as I am concerned, if Ben Lexcen wants to change his name, his country and his citizenship, he can join people like Senator Puplick and lose the respect of most people in this community who believe that the Australia Card will do something for ordinary, pay as you earn taxpayers in the community and those people who have a genuine right to social welfare benefits.

Let us go further about the nature of the debate. There has not been an issue debated at such length in this community for many years. The whole issue was raised at the Tax Summit in 1985. Papers have been put out by the Government ever since. There has been public discussion, which the Government deliberately activated. There has been a select committee, which examined hundreds of witnesses and took hundreds of written responses and submissions. There has been a debate on the report of the select committee. There have been two attempts by this Government to bring the Bill into this Parliament, and now we are coming back a third time. Overall, there has been a greater discussion of this issue than of any other issue brought before this Parliament.

This Government ought to be patted on the back because it has not tried to introduce a major innovation such as a national identification system through the back door. It has said, honestly, plainly and openly to the community, `We are going to bring in this system'. It is not some drivers' licence which will be upgraded later on through some ad hoc method to become eventually a de facto identification system. It is not a social security system that is upgraded in the same way as the Americans are upgrading theirs at the moment. It is not some sneaky method of numbering every citizen in Australia. We have said that we want an open debate about this issue because we believe that, on balance, the Australia Card will provide Australia with benefits which far outweigh any of the disadvantages of bringing in such a system.

There are people on this side of the chamber who have had questions to ask about the impact on privacy and civil liberties in this country of any introduction of an Australia Card or national identification system. I asked the same questions of myself. I opposed the Vietnam War. Everyone on this side of Parliament opposed the conscripting of 20-year-olds who did not then have a vote to go to fight an unjust, unreasonable and unwinnable war in Vietnam, whether they wanted to or not, and whose names were drawn out of a lottery barrel. We opposed that. That sits in our minds as the most important part of the Australian political landscape over the last 20 years. We are not about to give up civil liberties and privacies.

Most of us thought clearly and deeply about the effects of a national indentification system before we came down in favour of it. We debated it at our national conference, in our Caucus and our committees and we came to the conclusion that, on balance, an Australia Card system would give this community what it wanted, which was a fair tax system and a system of social security in which those who actually deserved social security benefits would get them. I notice that Senator Haines has just walked in with--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what she wants you to say.

—Yes, she wants me to see the protest written on her chest. That is about all she can get on-the ID card. Can I indicate quite clearly that when we looked at the balance of civil liberties and the benefits that would accrue to this community, in the end this Party was near unanimous. One has only to look at the vote at our national conference in Hobart to see just that. There was no attempt to hide it under the carpet. Let us get back to the basic question of how this system will work. I know that the major attack on the Australia Card has been that it will be ineffective. That is the second string to the bow of those people who, on the whole, do not care about civil liberties. I include most of the Opposition in that area. The members of the Joint Select Committee from the Liberal and National parties and the Democrats all agreed that the estimates of tax evasion in this country were conservative. All of them agreed that there ought to be some form of numbering system which would enable some matching to be done between social security and the Australian Taxation Office. All of them came to the conclusion that something had to be done about tax evasion in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get back to what the Government is doing. The Government has a two-pronged attack in respect of taxation. First, it wanted to broaden the tax base so that ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers would not have to shoulder the burden that was being avoided by a significant number of reasonably wealthy people in this community. We have broadened the tax base by introducing the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the tax on entertainment. Those taxes will net something like $2 billion. This has enabled us almost directly to provide over the last year or so tax cuts to ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers in the community. It has enabled us to drop the top rate of taxation from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar and to bring the other rates down correspondingly. It has enabled us to introduce the family assistance package which will in fact benefit those most in need. This is what has happened as a result of the broadening of the tax base.

We see the Australia Card as an attempt to stop tax cheating. There is no other way to stop tax cheating that will bring in the same types of returns. If we are able to bring in the Australia Card in sufficient time, if the card works as we say it will, we believe that in the long term enormous benefits will flow from the card and that this will be reflected directly in a number of areas, such as tax cuts, which the Government may choose to enter. I think there is a reasonable expectation that if the money brought in as a result of the Australia Card were used just to give tax cuts, we could again bring the top marginal rate down, this time from 49c in the dollar to 40c in the dollar.

It could be, for example, that we could choose not to give tax cuts but to give benefits in the pensions area. There is very good reason to believe that something like $8.50 a week extra could be given to every pensioner in this country-to every single supporting parent, to every old age pensioner and to every sickness beneficiary. Such an amount could be given to all of those people out there who need our assistance; the people who are waiting for something to be done about tax evasion in this country. Those benefits are very direct indeed.

I go on to the question of civil liberties. There has been an attempt on the part of opponents, not only those opposite us in this House but also those out in the community, to try to prove that the poor are going to be disadvantaged by the Australia Card, that they are the ones who will suffer as a result of the Australia Card being introduced, and that they are the ones who are going to be pushed around by the introduction of some plastic card. It ought to be said right at the outset that it is the poor, the disadvantaged, the people who are social security beneficiaries and are reliant on some form of welfare somewhere in the system, who are most often asked for proof of their identity and who are most often subjected to investigations, both financial and social, into their personal lives. They are the ones whom most of the middle class opponents opposite us forget about. The middle class opponents opposite us, often highly paid lawyers with `QC' after their names and living in reasonable affluence, forget the poor. They would not know what it is like to have to go somewhere along the line once every week or once every fortnight to produce proof of identity and to keep updating personal details in order that a government can give them some benefit. They would not know that because, apart from tax cuts, they have never had to ask for a benefit from the Government.

Let us look at what some of the welfare groups have to say. For example, the Sydney City Mission, an organisation for which I have enormous time and respect and which represents people who are really down and out, wrote to me about the Australia Card. It said:
Dear Senator Aulich,
As a welfare organisation, we would welcome the introduction of the Australia Card with a photograph.
The Card will provide a valuable means of identification for people with drug or alcohol related problems, the homeless, or families in need of emergency relief.
This would provide the best possible means of rationalising the distribution of moneys allocated to us by Government and help us deliver the money and services to those who most need it.

I am sure we can speak on behalf of all welfare organisations in saying that following the introduction of the Australia Card we would treat all our records in the strictest confidence just as we do at present.

Also, it is often said that welfare recipients are more likely to lose their cards than other members of the community. This is not true. Our people develop ingenious ways of looking after their few possessions. Many of them carry their Medicare cards in their shoe or other secure places.
The letter finishes on this note:

For welfare recipients more than most people in the Australian community the proposed national identity card with a photograph is a chance to be equal in a community that very often treats them as less than that.

That is a major welfare organisation right at the heart of welfare activity which deals with those who are most oppressed and down and out and which speaks on their behalf. They are not lawyers, QCs, affluent middle class people sitting back in their armchairs saying, `The poor don't like it because they might be impinged upon'. The fact is that the poor are already imposed upon and impinged upon, and the Australia Card will be one way of lessening some of that need to provide all sorts of identifications that are currently being demanded.
Let me mention, if that case is not enough, the view of Mrs Jackie Byrne, the Director of the Queensland Council of Social Service, who in her evidence to the Joint Select Committee said:

I meant to make the point when I stated that civil liberties are very much the province of the middle class. When you have to start thinking about where the food is coming from for the next week, you really do not have that liberty to think about those sorts of esoteric things. In theory we all ought to have the same civil liberties, but I think one of the major civil liberties is the right to be able to feed your kids, to see that your kids have the same education as the people down the road and to see that they have access to the same health and welfare services as everybody else. I think there are a couple of million Australians who are having their civil liberties grossly invaded because they do not have the same standard of living as the rest of the population. We are talking about 2.75 million people in this country living below the poverty line: 750,000 of them being children. That is a gross invasion of civil liberties as well.

One could go on to quote the view of the Salvation Army and I can produce letters from similar organisations to show that welfare organisations which represent the poor and down and out support the Australia Card because they know that the only way to get sufficient benefits to the right people, to their people, is to bring in this system which will bring in money from the tax evaders and which will make sure that those people who cheat on the social security system do not get away with it. Those organisations are right, and I believe that middle class people on the Opposition benches who for particular political reasons oppose the card are wrong.

Let us examine a few other areas that have been raised by Senator Puplick, in what I regarded as one of the greatest Shakespearian speeches in this debate, in regard to privacy and civil liberties in the private sector. We all know that in this area an enormous amount of information is held about people in private databanks. Whether they happen to be savings banks, trustee banks, consumer credit organisations and so on, I think there are some four million people on file through one consumer reference organisation in New South Wales. We all know that there is an exchange of personal information between those organisations, often without the customer's permission. What do the opponents of the Australia Card say about that? I have heard them say nothing on that aspect in this chamber. We have heard nothing from them about those processes, which occur around us every day. It is said that the right to have credit is optional, that one does not have to go out and borrow money, that somehow or other if one objects to having personal information about oneself being exchanged with other people, if one objects to having to give personal and private information to these organisations, one does not have to borrow money. I want to hear those people go out and tell the average young couple trying to get a house in the outskirts of Sydney or Melbourne that they do not have to go and borrow money. What will they do about people who have to borrow money to buy a car because public transport in their particular area is not sufficiently good to get them to work? What will they do about the borrowings that some people need in order to pay medical fees? I ask those questions because they have not been answered at any time in the debate.

Credit is not optional. If one has no credit in our society, if one cannot get access to credit and cannot borrow money, if one cannot produce a good credit record, one is dead. I defy anyone in this chamber to tell me that he or she has never borrowed money in his or her lifetime. Yet we, as a group, are reasonably affluent. All people in the community are ultimately forced to borrow money and that borrowing process is based very much on the provision and sharing of private information about themselves before they are finally given that loan. Let us not hear any more talk about the Government invading privacy when out there already there is an enormous uncontrolled sharing of information of the most personal and private kind to enable people to get loans to buy houses, cars and other essential items.

During the couple of minutes I have left I need to indicate quite clearly that this debate is not about a government attempting to number people for its own sake. It is not about imposing a system for its own sake. It is something that we have thought through and made a balanced judgment about. It is a process through which we have shared information with the whole community, a process whereby there has been an increased refinement of the way in which we will do things. It is a process whereby we have invited sensible, logical, rational people in the community to express themselves and provide advice. That process is still going on. The Government has indicated that it is prepared to amend the legislation in the future and to improve it. We do not want a third occasion of braying and shouting by honourable senators opposite in this chamber, of attempts to stir up fear in the community at large about this issue. We want positive alternatives put forward so that improvements can be made to the system and so that this country can be known for its fairness and equity, for its respect for a fair taxation system and a system which delivers to those people most in need that which they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the third time that the ID card legislation has been debated in the Parliament of Australia. We have heard nothing from the Government relating to this debate during the election campaign-or since it for that matter-that justifies this reintroduction of the legislation. Over recent weeks the Government has claimed that it has a mandate for what it is doing. It says that this mandate comes from the fact that it has won a record majority for a Labor Party in the House of Representatives. I point out to the numbers people in the Australian Labor Party that the Australian Federal Parliament consists of two Houses with equal rights and that no piece of legislation can pass the Parliament and become law until both Houses have approved it in an identical form. There is a very good reason for that. It is so this country does not become a dictatorship. The same election that increased the Government's majority in the lower House from 16 to 24, increased the majority against it in the Senate. The people of Australia believed that they should give the Labor Party a third term-although reasons for that escape me. Nevertheless, they decided not to give the Government a majority in the Senate. At least that was a sensible decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority of Australians in the last election campaign actually had no idea at all that there was a joint sitting hanging at the end of this. The print media in particular did very little to make them aware of that fact, despite the fact that, in the Press Gallery in Canberra at least, most are of an age and of sufficient journalistic experience to have remembered-or they ought to have remembered it-the joint sitting that we had previously. It is within living political memory. Yet, that was not brought forward by anybody except me, I think, on radio programs around Australia. It was certainly not a feature in the Press of Australia. We had an election result that certainly returned the Government with an increased majority in the House of Representatives. But its majority in the Senate was decreased, I believe, because the people of Australia felt that the Senate would reject the Australia Card for the third time-and properly so-should the Government reintroduce it. The Government has claimed in recent days that no one has challenged the costings of this card. That is about the only new argument that Mr Hawke and his minions have been able to come up with.

One then has to ask the question: which costings? How old are the costings that we are supposed to be challenging and where do they stem from? The Government claimed some two years ago that a national identification system in Australia would cost $1 billion to set up. It was not going to raise any revenue in excess of that expenditure for five years. Then according to Senator Tate's comments on the Opposition's urgency motion earlier this week, the Bill was going to raise $4.5 billion over 10 years. That is a little less than $500m annually. To the best of my knowledge the Government has not adjusted any of those claims about how much money it will raise, not withstanding the fact that earlier this year it implemented two significant changes to the tax and social security systems, that is, a crack-down on social security fraud which has apparently netted in the vicinity of $183m and an increased strength of tax audits on companies whose profits are in excess, I think, of $100m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not merely companies.

—Indeed, no. According to reports in the paper from Mr Trevor Boucher, the Commissioner of Taxation, the Government has raised on average an extra $2.5m from each of the companies audited. It is now planning on inserting an auditor, so to speak, into some of the major companies around Australia in order to ensure that revenue is not slipping through its fingers. I understand that some hundreds of millions of dollars of increased revenue are estimated to be raised from that tax audit system. So we now have in the vicinity of an extra $350m already raised by two methods that the Government has introduced without the benefit of the Australia Card. Yet the Government is not telling us whether this is in addition to the money that it laughingly suggests is going to come from the Australia Card or whether it is a significant part of it. If the former is true I would like to know where the arithmetic is coming from. If the latter is true, the Government has just removed any financial grounds for arguing for the implementation of what is essentially an intrusive, expensive and ineffective system. The Government has not told us how the system is going to produce the benefits that it alleges will flow from it. While on the one hand it is telling those of us who oppose it that we have not challenged its costings, the Government itself has not been telling us how it is going to achieve the benefits in cutting back tax and social security fraud that it constantly tells us it will do.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the implementation of a national identification system will not significantly affect the cash economy. We know that it will not eliminate crime, whether professional or enthusiastic amateur, in this country. How can it? It has never achieved that in any European or North American country. Nor will it effectively eliminate the problem of illegal immigration. We have in the community some people telling us that it is fine for Australia to have an ID card system. After all, they say, America has its social security card. Without going into the more or less voluntary nature of that card, I point out that, while that card has to be produced before people can get employment, it has not stopped hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants going north into America to pick up seasonal work. The requirement for a card to be produced has not cut back on illegal immigration in the United States at all.
