In the European countries that have some form of national identification system-which, I might add, they tend to use as an internal passport-the black economy, the black market, is still very much in evidence. I have not noticed any diminution in the activities of mafia-like organisations across Europe.

So for the Government to argue that an ID card is necessary to cut back on tax and social security fraud, the majority of which comes not from false identification but from failure to state income accurately, or to say that it is going to cut back on criminal tax fraud or illegal immigration, is a nonsense. There is no country in the world the Government can point to which has a system such as that proposed in Australia, or any sort of national ID card system, which has managed to stop those problems. Nor, of course, have such systems been able to cut down on people who are holding down more than one job.

Senator Aulich claimed somewhat plaintively, if not ingenuously, during his contribution that pensioners and low income earners would receive an extra $8 per week if this ID system were introduced. That is arrant nonsense. I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, whether the Government has passed on to pensioners or low income earners the revenue of nearly $350m that I mentioned a little while ago, raised from the tax and social security crack-downs implemented this year. Of course it has not. What the Government did in the Budget was to use up those savings to revenue, giving another tax concession to the well-off by using the savings to offset the costs of the reintroduction of negative gearing. If Senator Aulich were still in the chamber I would say to him that it is about time he stopped being so naive. As he is not, I will say it anyway and he can read it in Hansard. His claim is as silly and as untrue as the cheap shot that is inevitably fired across the bows of the opponents of the ID card-that the only people who oppose the legislation are either tax and social security cheats themselves or supporters of tax and social security cheats. That is one of the six great lies of the Australia Card. The Government claims it is the only way to stop tax and social security cheats and that if one were in favour of stopping them and not supportive of those anti-social people, one would get behind it.

We all know that the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, set up in late 1985 and which reported in mid-1986, said that the proposed system `will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud'. It based that statement on some of the things that I have already mentioned. The system cannot stop the cash economy. How on earth is the possession of a green and gold bit of plastic with one's photograph on it, or a microchip in the top left hand corner, or a magnetic strip on the back, or anything else that goes whizz-bang in the night, going to cut back on the cash economy? How is it going to make someone who is paid in cash run off to the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security and say, `Look at what I have just earned'? Is there some sort of elastic thread that we do not know about that connects us to the card and the card to those two departments?

The only way the cash economy will be dealt with in any way at all through the introduction of a national identification system and the plastic card that goes with it is if we, the people who have our homes cleaned for cash, our lawns mowed for cash, our windows washed for cash, or a pergola built for cash-we, the payers-every week, or every time we pay someone in cash, report to the Taxation Office or the Social Security Department the ID card number of the person we have so employed. That would reverse the normal onus that we in this country pride ourselves on. As a democratic country we assume innocence until guilt is proven. For us as householders, to have to go through the process of assuming that the person who is earning $20 for spending a couple of hours cleaning a house or mowing a lawn is defrauding the system is appalling. Australia is certainly not the country I thought it was if that sort of system were implemented. And it is the only system that can be implemented if we want the ID card system effectively to crack down on the cash economy.

As far as criminal fraud or criminal behaviour of any sort is concerned, the ID card is worse than useless. It is worse than useless because it confers a validity on the holder that may not be justified. The reason for that is that the identifying data-the documents that may be required to be produced to prove that one is who one says one is-have an appallingly low integrity. What is the point of having a system which is supposed to be high in integrity and that everybody can trust if it is based on three pieces of data which we all know to be so limited in integrity as to make them virtually useless?

Birth certificates will not have any validity at all attached to them until we introduce certainly what is suggested as part of this legislation-but first; not last-and that is a nationalised computerisation of births, deaths and marriages. Until that is done there will always be the possibility of people acquiring birth certificates that are not theirs by right and then using them to get passports, ID cards and whatever else. To then turn around and say that a passport has some validity, when it is based on a possibly fraudulent birth certificate, compounds the problem. Then to suggest that to validate one's claim that one is who one says one is for the purpose of acquiring an ID card, one produce a flawed birth certificate, a highly improbable passport and a tax file number that has no integrity at all in this country is to force a monstrosity on this country that would be comical if it were not that it had such tragic potential. That is the first of the six great lies of the Australia Card: It is the only way to stop tax and social security cheats!

The next lie, associated with that, is that if one has nothing to hide one has nothing to fear. Tell that to the New South Wales surgeons who discovered that their quarterly income from one quarter in 1985 was appearing on the front pages of New South Wales papers courtesy of a truck, apparently driven by a departmental employee of the Health Insurance Commission, that dropped the document off its back.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much do they earn anyway-$3m?
—It is not relevant how much they earn. They are entitled to the privacy of that information.
—Why would they want to hide it?

—I have no time for Bruce Shepherd, et al who held the New South Wales hospital system to ransom, demanding more money. But it was not anybody's right to release confidential information in an attempt to sway public opinion against the doctors. If the Government has to resort to that, it is pretty inefficient indeed. Regarding the argument that if one has nothing to hide one has nothing to fear, tell that to the 16- and 17-year-old girls in Victoria who arrived home one afternoon to find the police on their doorsteps saying, `We understand from information we have received from the Health Insurance Commission that you had a termination performed on you by a certain doctor and we are charging that doctor for illegal activities. We want you to give evidence against him in a court of law'. I presume that that is of no concern to people on the other side of this chamber. Do not tell me that if one has nothing to hide one has nothing to fear. The honourable senator should try convincing those girls and their families first and when he has convinced them, he should come back and try to convince me. He will not do it otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there is the argument: `It is only another piece of plastic like a Bankcard, like a drivers licence, like an Amex card with your photograph on it'. That is just as much rubbish as the previous two assertions. The Australia Card is not just another piece of plastic; it is the visible part of a vast computer network that will process and circulate information about every one of us. The card is not the danger-we all carry bits of plastic for one reason or another-it is what the card symbolises. The huge data base behind it is what terrifies so many concerned Australians. Senator Aulich said, `But information is collected on all of us in all sorts of areas around Australia. The bank knows a lot about you if you make a loan application. Finance companies know about you if you need a loan to buy a new car'. Certainly all sorts of people in the community know a fair amount about us but it is in-house information, or should be, and would be if this Government, in its previous three years in office had done something useful such as introduce across the board privacy legislation that affected the private sector as well as the public sector.

In this country we protect all sorts of commercial data. One cannot get information under freedom of information legislation about the commercial activities of a company because that information is considered sacrosanct. If the Government is prepared to protect information contained in company documents, why is it not prepared to act to protect the privacy of individuals who most certainly do have a vast array of information held on them by a variety of organisations, from banks to retail outlets through to used car sales people. Of course we need privacy legislation but we need it first, not after the event. The problem with the information that will be collected and collated on us through the centralised data system of the national identification card is that it will be accessible in toto to some 2,000 public servants.

The fourth argument raised by proponents of the card is that other countries have them so it must be okay. A variation on that argument is: `But we had them during the war'. We also had food rationing, blackouts and curfews during the war. Those things occur these days only in countries which have military dictatorships. While I do not want to make any assertions about what this Government might or might not become in a couple of years, at the moment we do not have a military dictatorship and we do not need the sorts of intrusive systems, impediments and restrictions that we happily accept under wartime conditions because we have the nation's security at risk. Furthermore, as I said earlier, those countries which have ID cards have not found them useful for cutting back on tax and social security fraud, criminal or otherwise. In the main they use them as internal passports. So the reason for introducing them was different.

The Government says that the Australia Card will be forge-proof. That does not need to be challenged in any way at all. It is so patently absurd as to be laughable. There is not a card around-smart cards, cards with holograms on them, strangely shaped cards, multicoloured cards, magnetic cards, striped cards or what have you-that somebody cannot forge. If one has the technology to produce the card somebody else has the technology to reproduce it.

A rather frightening aspect to me has been reports in the paper recently that a smart card is on line some few years down the track. A smart card was used as an exhibit to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. There it was, in all its radiant glory, with a little microchip the size of a 5c piece in the top left hand corner. I suggest to anybody here who is as likely to lose bits of plastic around the place as I am that it is a really terrific idea to think that some time down the track we are going to have a card with a microchip in it! If we lose it or if it is stolen, not only can it be used by somebody with a compatible system to find out what is on the chip, but also the chip can be changed; it can be reprogrammed. I wonder how many ordinary, individual human beings are going to win in a fight with the computer, if that ever happens.

The last of the absurdities that are raised is that the Data Protection Agency will protect our privacy. Oh, come on now! Again, if we are to have some sort of privacy legislation, some sort of data protection agency, it should be implemented first so that we can find out how effective it is in stopping things from dropping off the back of the Health Insurance Commission trucks. Let us give it a bit of a trial, shall we, before we launch this system will-nilly on to 16 million Australians who will assume that the privacy is being protected, that the data held on them is being protected.

I point out one other thing that seems to have been overlooked in this discussion about data protection agencies. At the very best they are, like our police forces, after-the-event agencies. Our police forces are not here in order that we have no murders, no rapes, no robberies and no looting and pillaging. It might be nice if they could prevent them but they cannot. We all acknowledge that. The purpose of our police forces is, with a bit of luck, to apprehend the criminal and, with a bit more luck in the judicial system, to get a penalty applied. But the damage has still been done. Whatever penalties are to apply to people who leak information and who are caught by the Data Protection Agency-whatever else happens-the fact remains that the information will have been leaked. People put in the position of those 16- and 17-year-olds in Victoria will get precious little satisfaction out of that.

The Government is undoubtedly putting the cart before the horse. It has said to opponents of the legislation: `Produce your ideas'. Government members should go back and read, assuming that they can-those of them who are so much in favour of this system-the majority report of the joint parliamentary committee. It recommended firstly the nationalisation and computerisation of the births, deaths and marriages system, without which nothing of any integrity at all can be implemented. It recommended increasing the integrity of the tax file number and then using it for certain financial transactions, but only after its integrity had been increased. It recommended the use of a withholding tax on bank accounts accruing interest which did not have a tax file number attached to them. These measures will raise the sort of revenue still to be raised after the last two systems put into operation by the Government-the crackdown on tax and social security fraud I mentioned earlier. These three measures will pick up the extra revenue the Government is aiming for.

Senator Aulich called for suggestions for improvements of the Australia Card legislation. I say to him: stop trying to improve something that is not able to be improved. Go back to square one. Go on from the changes to the tax and social security system that the Government has already implemented and start improving the systems that are there, before foisting on Australia an expensive, ineffective and intrusive system that cannot hope to achieve what the Government wants it to achieve.

The reasons for opposing the card involve principle and practicality. They are not based on support for cheating and fraud in the tax and social security systems. The Government may well have backed itself into a corner over this issue but I say to the Government, as other opponents of this card have already said: `If you have any integrity at all you will admit your error; go back to the starting point and bring in the recommendations of the joint parliamentary committee majority report. You will not then need to give 16 million Australians a useless piece of plastic to get muddled up with the others they carry in their pockets'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to overestimate the importance of this legislation. In my judgment, the Australia Card Bill 1986 is probably the most important piece of legislation ever to come before the Australian Parliament. I would like to compliment the previous speakers in this debate from this side of the chamber on the excellence of their contributions. Senator Haines and Senator Puplick both made outstanding speeches. But far more relevant than that is the importance of what they had to say. I come back to the point that never before has such important legislation been placed before the Australian people. Today we are considering legislation which absolutely cuts the democratic basis from under Australian society and which reduces us all to `card subjects', to `entities entitled to operate'-number carriers.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want a piece of plastic. If the Government is going to do that to me, let it put the number on my arm in the way governments did in other totalitarian states. That is what the Government is doing with its legislation. That is the state this free country will be reduced to when the Moscow card is introduced and the arrogant Keating and the arrogant Hawke are running as the totalitarian rulers of Australia in five or six years time. They will have total control of the Australian community. They will know everything. They will blackmail and bludgeon everyone into submission through the administration of this system.

This is the most dangerous, repressive and regressive legislation that has ever been introduced into this Parliament. In a sense, it is a reversion to type for the Labor Party. Just as in the period after the Second World War, when I was a child, the Chifley Labor Government introduced the bank nationalisation Bill which produced a revolt and which led to the Chifley Government being thrown out of office, now we have another manifestation of the same sort of totalitarian thinking-the Moscow card, the identity card the Government is now proposing to bring in.

The Australia Card Bill will not work. It will not catch tax evaders. It will not catch social security cheats. It will not catch illegal migrants. So the reason for bringing it in does not exist. It will destroy individual privacy. It will reduce even the Labor members of parliament to `card subjects', to `entities entitled to operate'. It will not only destroy our privacy, but also it will reverse the traditional onus of proof in a common law country, that one is innocent until the Government proves one is guilty. It is being introduced with horrendous penalties. If the ordinary housewife does not sight an Australia Card before she signs on a baby-sitter, she is up for a $20,000 fine. The cost of implementation is huge and unquantifiable. We hear a great deal from the Government about what it might cost to bring in. We hear very little about the cost to industry. We are looking at a cost to Australia of hundreds of billions of dollars for this futile scheme. Finally, it will aid and protect organised crime in Australia in a way that it never has been protected before.

We hear a little bit of nonsense from the Prime Minister that he has a mandate to do this. As I informed Senator Ray yesterday, that is some mandate. He got 16,900-odd fewer votes in the election on 11 July than the Liberal and National parties got, but he got a bonus of 24 seats, thanks to the rigging of the boundaries. Do not tell me that he has a mandate to proceed with any Australia Card legislation.

I would like to take the Government on with the argument that it will not work. The reason why we have problems with tax evasion, the reason why we have problems with social security cheats and the reason why we have problems with illegal migrants, have nothing to do with the absence of a Moscow card: they have everything to do with administrative inefficiency in the Australian Public Service. The imposition of different legislation will do nothing to cure or correct the managerial inefficiency in the Public Service.

If I might divert for a moment, after 4 1/2 years of Labor rule, I have never known a time in the years I have lived in Australia when the Public Service was held in more disregard for its inefficient operation and its lack of accountability than has been the case since it has been politicised with the pork barrelling of the Labor Party for its friends being put into senior positions.

Let us look at the tax position. The basic inefficiency of the Australian Taxation Office is the reason why people do not pay what they should pay in tax. All of us want to pay tax on a fair and equitable basis. We all want to have an equal accountability to the Tax Office. We do not want some people to evade tax and others to be taxed to make up for the deficit. But as Senator Puplick said, the fact that the Office has refused to spend half of what it has been allocated in recent years to modify and improve its computer systems speaks for itself. The Australian Taxation Office has failed, as reports have shown, to collect more than a small percentage of interest payments from bank accounts, building societies and other interest-paying bodies. There is no excuse for that. Above everything else, the Australian Taxation Office has shown that it has a failure of will to implement the laws that are on the statute books in the way they should be implemented. So until the Office fixes its house up, any sort of different system will have no effect whatsoever.

On social security fraud, it is very strange that once upon a time whenever anyone in this Parliament talked about dole bludgers, the Labor Party took off in high dudgeon and high morality and it was very upset by that term. But all we hear today is a litany, from Senator Ryan downwards, that we have to catch the dole bludgers and that the Australia Card will catch them. That is nonsense. Very little social security fraud turns on mistaken or misrepresentation of identity. Most of it turns on misrepresentation of income and people having several jobs. In practice the Australia Card will not do anything to correct that situation. We had the example some months ago of the Social Security Department doing an audit on 4,000 people receiving dole payments. If found that 1,000-25 per cent-were not entitled to get it. It did not need an Australia Card to do that. It just needed to get off its bottom and shuffle a few papers to find out to whom it was paying money. That is the way to handle this problem. Again, it is an administrative inefficiency.

I turn to the field of illegal immigrants. As I have said before in this place, the ritual figure of illegal immigrants in Australia that comes from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is always around 25,000 to 30,000. I believe it is at least 10 times higher. It might be 20 times higher. The facts are that these people are coming in and living in closed societies. The health inspectors, the thugs from the union movement, cannot get in to find out whether these people have union cards or anything like that. They beat the bully boys because someone stands in front of the building and says, `I don't understand what you are talking about. We do not speak English', and that sort of thing. People selling Australia Cards to illegal immigrants will not make one sale. It just will not happen. So the whole basis for the introduction of this card is impractical. It will not work; it will not attain the goals. If it is not going to work, why should we go ahead with it?

There will be some very serious and profound consequences if we go ahead with this card. First, we will have the destruction of individual privacy. Everyone has talked about individual privacy and it is a very real point to Liberals because we believe in the supreme importance of individual personality. That leads me to another point. What is being destroyed here is not only our individual privacy, but also our personality because we are reduced all the way through this Bill-130 pages of print-to `card subjects'. We are only `entities entitled to operate'. We are not human beings. We are not Australian citizens. We are not Liberal voters or Labor voters, or anything like that. We are a dehumanised card subject. That is what we are: an alphanumeric number which will probably run to about 20 characters. I do not like that. I will not have that for Australia and neither will anyone else in this country. Where we find the Government described, it is always described as the `Authority' with a capital letter. It is Big Brother with capital letters.

That point takes me back to my youth when I was a student and all those novels used to be written by refugees from behind the Iron Curtain and other totalitarian countries. They were on the theme of, `Who am I? Where am I in this world? Am I an individual?'. I could not understand that as an Australian growing up in a free democratic society. I could not understand how people could be troubled about who they were in this world, because I knew who I was and all my friends knew who they were. This Bill will not only destroy our privacy, but also it will destroy our personalities. We are already well down the track in the psychological warfare being waged by the totalitarian elements in the bureaucratic regime when we are described as `card subjects' not as Australians.

Implicit in this, of course, is the reversal of common law which Senator Puplick talked about, in which the reversal of onus of proof takes place. It will be mandatory under this system for the individual to be able to prove that he is innocent in order to escape the penalties of the law in whatever field he is operating in. That might seem an academic point for some people, but it is a most sinister and malignant difference.

Privacy will be destroyed by the fact that we have a linkage system now set up. We will have a common alphanumeric number for everyone. We have files at present, as various speakers on the other side have said. Everyone must have a medical file because we have a universal health system. Everyone must have a taxation file because every income earner must pay tax. We must have a social security file even if we are employed and not receiving the unemployment benefit. Most of us receive a family allowance, or something like that which occasions a social security file being raised on us. But the essential difference between the ways things are today and what is being proposed by the totalitarian regime is that we will now be identified by a common number-we are not at the present time-and there will be cross-linking between the files that are held.

Our forebears-or a large number of them-came here 200 years ago linked in iron chains. Those people were later unfettered. But now, 200 years later, we are being offered the proposition that we should be linked in unbreakable electronic chains, from which we cannot be unfettered, through the Australia Card system. All the glib proposals that have come from the Australian Labor Party to protect our privacy are absolutely meaningless. It is impossible to do and, furthermore, the Government has shown a total inability to understand the complexities of the situation. If one listens to Senator Ryan talking about this matter, it becomes quite obvious that her knowledge of computerisation techniques and practices is about as profound as my knowledge of Patagonian hermaphrodites. She simply could not enter her own name into a computer.

What has the Government done so far? What is its track record in protecting privacy? The Health Insurance Commission is the Government's chosen agent to introduce the system for the protection of the privacy of the Australian citizen. As Senator Puplick said, the Commission has a sleazy record. I am much more circumspect and diplomatic in my language; I would say that it has both a dishonourable and a dishonest record. Look at the way it has leaked information on doctors' incomes and the way it has sold patient records in the past. We can have absolutely no confidence in this scheme. Having been involved in the health professions for a large part of my life before I entered the Senate, I can say this with absolute certainty: patients are entitled to have total security of their medical records. One cannot take an accurate medical case history from a patient if he believes that it will be broadcast all over the community. It is one of the fundamental rights of patients to have privacy of their personal affairs. Many people in Australia are sick, and there is, regrettably, an intolerance in the community to infirmity, particularly among employers. They may not employ someone if they know he has a history of a carcinoma or some other malignant disease. It may be treatable or it may be quite inactive; or maybe a cure has been effected. Similarly, they will not employ anyone who has a history of psychiatric treatment. It just does not happen. Yet confidence in the maintenance of secrecy of patients' records simply does not exist with the Health Insurance Commission.

The Government now proposes that there will be a Data Protection Agency. It is modelled on the Swedish example because most of the Government's ideas, insofar as the Labor Party has ideas, come out of Sweden. But the data protection agency in Sweden has been run up by a chap called Mr Jan Freese. After 12 years he has resigned in total despair at the failure of the model which the Australian Government is proposing. Let us look at the American experience. Unlike Australia, America has legislation controlling the confidentially of data held in computer files. The latest congressional inquiry has shown that this legislation has been a massive failure; it does not work.

The final proposal offered this week is the dedicated landlines proposition. Let me say that no member of the Government knows any more about that than Mr Duncan or Senator Gareth Evans knows about the Amann Aviation business. What is the Government talking about when it talks about dedicated landlines? The Government is trying to tell us that somehow or other it has a secure system of transferring information from one office to another-absolute bunkum. It is just not possible to do it the way the Government says it will do it. Will it dig trenches between Brisbane and Sydney and Sydney and Melbourne, with one going to Longreach and another to Port Lincoln and all the other places? Will it connect all the offices and run a secure system? If it does that, how many thousands of billions of dollars will it require?

Let me tell the Government what has been going on in the defence field. The Australian Government, from a time before I entered the Parliament-which is now some 10 years ago-has been trying to set up a secure defence communications system, the DISCON system or defence integrated secure communications network. We have spent over $400m and we have very little to show for it. The point is that creating secure communications is an enormously difficult and horrendously expensive technical procedure, and the Government has no concept of how it will do it in relation to the personal data that will be acquired through the Australia Card system.

We cannot maintain privacy; we cannot control access to that information. We cannot prevent greater accretion of information. As Senator Puplick said, it is only this week that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) has called for his files to be added to the system. We do not know what the Government will be holding on us. There was a release this week of secret briefing papers saying that the Government would show citizens only what it thought the citizens were entitled to know. That is a frightening indication of what faces us. The Government wants to get information about every Australian citizen so it can blackmail the community into submission. Look at the arrogance of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating today and just think of what it will be like when they just have to press a button to know the most intimate details of one's whole life.

I turn now to the horrendous penalties provided for under the Australia Card Bill. For many breaches of the legislation the individual will be fined $20,000-for a quite minor infringement. Companies will be fined $100,000. Do not believe any of this business that people will not be compelled to carry their cards. It will be a fact of life that we will be compelled to carry our cards to do any sort of business in Australia.

This leads me to the costs of implementation. We have got no figures of any meaning out of the Government for what the system will cost to implement. We have heard the rubbery figure of 2,000 public servants to implement the scheme. Senator Ryan, in a Four Corners interview I heard about four of five weeks ago, said that we would have secure photographic services. Our mug shots to go on the card will not be taken by our friendly photographer down at the corner; they will be taken by a government employee. How many thousands or tens of thousands of photographers will have to be employed, and at what cost, just to do that?

The implementation of this measure will cost the Government billions. But, at the same time, the cost to business is unquantifiable. We get back to the age old Labor principle that the citizen always pays twice. Just as we pay 1.25 per cent of our income without any ceiling for Medicare, and around another $1,000 for family cover to get decent medical treatment, so it is with this system. We will pay both the costs to government of implementing the card system and the cost to business-and this at a time when Australia is struggling to be competitive in the world to get our costs down and pay off the huge debts that the Labor Party has left us with.

One will not be able to open a bank account; one will not be able to buy or sell any land or property; one will not be able to open a safety deposit box; one will not be able to get rent paid for a property unless the real estate agent sees one's Australia Card. And when one gets a heart attack from what the system will do, one will not even be able to be admitted to hospital without an Australia Card. The cost cannot be quantified but it will run into hundreds of millions of dollars.

Finally, the card will aid and protect the criminals in the Australian community. The card will be very easily forged when money is no object. It does not matter what system is introduced; when money is no object it can be beaten. The recent inquiry in Queensland has been a revelation to most of the people of Australia about the extent of money involved in organised crime today. We are talking about millions or maybe billions of dollars a month in profits coming out of organised crime. It is just chicken feed for criminals to forge any system that is introduced. The danger is that once we set up this system, which is a one check system instead of having a multitude of checks to establish people's identity, which presently exists, once the first gate is passed through they are beyond challenge from then on. That is why Commissioner Costigan, and anyone else who has studied this position, has come out so strongly against the Australia Card system.

The Australia Card system will not harass in any way at all the organised criminals in society, but it will harass the working mothers of Australia and the couples whose wives go out to work, and they form nearly a majority of the population today. They need baby-sitters for their children while they are at work and they need women to do a bit of cleaning in the house or in the apartment for a few hours and to do a bit of ironing. They will have to ask the people who come in to help them to produce an Australia Card, otherwise they will face a penalty of about $20,000. This will lead to a diminution of the taxation base, the very converse of what the proponents of the card say. They say that we need the card to get more tax money in and to make sure that everyone pays tax. The existence of this legislation-and the requirement for the card to be seen before any transaction takes place-means that people will deal out of the inside of their coat pockets. The cash economy will get the biggest boost it ever has. In countries where this system operates we find between 20 and 60 per cent or more of transactions in the economy take place on a cash basis with no records.

Having dealt with the shortcomings of this legislation, let us look outside this chamber at what is going on in the public today. The first point to make is that there has never been any problem with identity in Australia. As individual Australians, we have never had any difficulty in showing who we were. More importantly, there has never been a petition to this Parliament saying, `Give us an identity card'. There is no public demand for this in any way at all. There was no mandate for it implicit in the last election. If we look at the polling position outside we will find that the overwhelming majority of Australians do no want a bar of this system. In my own State yesterday radio station 4CA in Cairns received 597 calls in half an hour in response to a phone-in about the Australia Card. That is not a bad record. Ninety per cent of the respondents-this in an isolated country town-were against the card.

Anyone in the Labor Party or in the Ministry with any sensitivity ought to be very worried at the present total public opposition. But, naively or stupidly, they do not seem to be worried. Daily we hear statements from Senator Ryan and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the legislation is faulty. That raises another question. What is the Government doing? If the Government admits to major defects in the legislation, how can it proceed if it has any intelligence, any integrity, any responsibility at all? No government says, `We are going to bring legislation in. We know that it is no good; we know that it has to be amended'. That is just not done, but apparently this Government is going go to it. Why is the Government allowed to do it? We have a Senate which is controlled by the Left and the far Left of the Labor Party. Where are those successors to Senator Georges? Where are the people such as Senator Burns, Senator Childs and the rest, with their passionate beliefs in the principles of the far Left and their opposition to this card? When are they going to do what their conscience dictates and vote against it? Were they bought off with the security of a Senate seat for the next three years? What a state the Labor Party has sunk to when the majority of its members loathe and despise what is being done to them with the Australia Card. The only one of them who had any backbone, any integrity at all, Senator George Georges, was expelled from the Party for doing what his conscience dictated. Where does that leave honourable senators opposite? Why do they not just hide behind their desks?

This is the most dangerous, the most repressive and the most regressive legislation that has ever been introduced into this Parliament. It is the most undemocratic because it will destroy the principles on which Australian society has been founded. It will not work. It will remove Australia from the ranks of the great Western democracies and reduce us to the level of a third rate police state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak in favour of the Australia Card Bill 1986 (No. 3). In my remarks today I wish to raise three matters. The first deals with the question of the Government's mandate. The second deals with the question of civil liberties and how that has been used in the debate by the opponents to attack the card. I wish thirdly to deal with a matter raised by Senator MacGibbon in his remarks about dedicated landlines and their so-called misuse or the ability to overcome their integrity, enabling people to get information.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer first to the history of the Australia Card. I must confess that I first heard of the card when it was mooted by Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association over two and a half years ago. Because of Eric Risstrom's record, I had some doubt about the proposal. I thought that, as a noted and self-confessed sympathiser of the Liberal Party was putting up something like that, it must be suspect. But the more I thought about it and the more I studied it, the more I thought I could see a good reason for it to be supported. But I really became a convinced supporter of the Australia Card when a large number of lawyers in the community started attacking the idea and using the, in my view, false argument of civil liberties against the introduction of the card. I believe that many people in the law profession have a vested interest in ensuring that the Australia Card is not introduced. Their incomes are directly related to protecting and acting for clients in various industries-in tax avoidance and commercial transactions-who have done very well out of not having an Australia Card operating in this country. Therefore, in the debates in my own Party over the last two years I have always been a strong supporter of the Australia Card.

I want to correct a statement that Senator Bjelke-Petersen made two days ago when she said that the South Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party opposes the introduction of the Australia Card. That is an absolute untruth. In last year's June convention there was a very vigorous debate within the democratic procedures of our Party in South Australia and our State branch voted by a considerable-(Quorum formed) As I was saying before the quorum was called, there was a vigorous debate within the South Australian branch of the Labor Party. Senator Bolkus, who is just leaving the chamber, was a participant in the debate that took place at the June 1986 annual State convention. As he is entitled to do within the ALP, he expressed his view openly and democratically. But the vote was substantially in favour of the introduction of the Australia Card. So our State branch, despite what Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen said yesterday--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your State branch is broke.
—We also happen to have been the Government in South Australia for 18 of the last 22 years, much to the honourable senator's disappointment.
—You're a great one to be talking about finance. The State Branch of the ALP is $1m in debt and you were the secretary.

—We have won plenty of elections in South Australia, much to the honourable senator's disappointment; I know all about that. In July of last year the National Conference of our Party also debated the issue and carried a resolution and amendments to the platform that clearly stated that the Party's position was that it was in favour of the introduction of the Australia Card. That, again, came after vigorous debate at that National Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: I find amazing the claim that this Government does not have the mandate to debate and again bring into this Parliament a Bill to introduce the Australia Card. To me it seems extremely odd that this should be said when a double dissolution was caused by the Senate voting twice to reject legislation. The constitutional requirement is well known within the community. People say that the Australia Card was not really a major issue in the campaign. I note that the other day Senator Haines said that she raised the issue of the Australia Card during the Federal election campaign. I agree with her: to my recollection, on several occasions in South Australia, during the campaign, Senator Haines raised the issue of the Australia Card. She may not have got as much publicity as she would have liked from the media, but she did campaign on it. Although this was the first occasion on which a candidate, I had the opportunity to respond in the Press to Senator Haines's remarks in opposition to the Australia Card. Certainly I think Senator Haines ought to be commended for taking every chance she had to raise the issue. But the problem that she has is that the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia refused to run on the issue in the campaign. They ran absolutely dead. Mr Howard, the Leader of the Liberal Party, openly admitted after the election that they gave it the big miss because they were afraid that they would lose votes on it. They read their own Party research which showed that a majority of Australians were in favour of the introduction of the Australia Card.

Why should the Government be blamed when the Opposition refused to campaign on the issue on which the double dissolution was called? Mr Howard wanted to spend most of his time trying to explain a tax package that did not add up. I suppose one of the reasons he did not get on to the Australia Card, even if he had wanted to, was that he was always on the back foot trying to explain a set of policies which no one could understand.

Comments have been made about the result of the election. It is now being said that because more voters voted for the combined parties represented in the Senate than for the Labor Government, in some way the Australia Card is not part of our mandate. I have to remind honourable senators that the Government is created in the House of Representatives. Whether honourable senators opposite like it or not, we have a majority of 24 seats there on boundaries that are fairly drawn. The imputation that Senator MacGibbon made that those boundaries are rigged is a disgraceful attack on the integrity and the honesty of the independent Australian Electoral Commission established by this Parliament. I only wish that Senator MacGibbon and his Party in Queensland and the Country Party, now the National Party, had not, for the last 30-odd years squibbed introducing fair boundaries in that State. If they had, not only might the Labor Party have been in government but, in fact, even the Liberal Party might have been the majority party in coalition in Queensland. But Senator MacGibbon's Party has squibbed that issue for nearly 30 years. He made a disgraceful attack today on the honesty and integrity of the independent Electoral Commission.

We won the election. We accept the fact that we do not have the numbers in the Senate to have the legislation passed. However, the Constitution which has been in place since 1901 provides very clearly that, after a double dissolution, if the Bill is again defeated in the Senate there will be a joint sitting of both Houses. Opposition members may not like it but we like it. We will have a majority in the Joint Sitting and the Bill will be passed. We will do that in accordance with the Constitution of Australia.

For years I have heard Opposition senators defending the Constitution and saying what a great document it is. There are many aspects of the Constitution that I would like to see reformed. However, the joint sitting provision has been there for the last 86 years since Federation during which time nobody on the opposite side of politics has ever proposed changing that joint sitting provision which is now going to come into play in the next six to seven months of this term of the Parliament. So after this legislation is debated in the Joint Sitting it will be carried in accordance with the Constitution of Australia. I am very thankful that it will be because the Australia Card is the major plank on which the double dissolution was called.

The Democrats were delighted that a double dissolution was called because it meant that several more Democrats were elected to this chamber than would have been the case had a half Senate election been held. It is ironical in a sense that the Democrats, who are back here with seven senators, are here because of a Bill which they used to trigger the double dissolution. It is a Bill which has enhanced their survival and some of us in the major parties might think that that is one of the unfortunate circumstances of the double dissolution.

I would also say to the people in the community and even to some people in the labour movement who want a referendum instead of a joint sitting, that I think that it would be a tragic mistake, for the labour movement in particular, ever to consider that a joint sitting should not take place, that we cannot have a double dissolution when we are thwarted in the Senate with our legislation. If at some future time we give way on this Bill on the Australia Card, this will be used as an excuse when a reform of a Labor government is stopped in the Senate following another double dissolution. People will say, `Don't worry about dealing with an issue after a double dissolution; forget all about it'. Such a practice will be used to stop reform being introduced by a Labor government. Imagine what would have happened after the double dissolution in 1974 if we had said that we were going to forget a couple of the Bills that went through the Joint Sitting. The labour movement all around Australia would quite rightly have been up in arms and saying that it was a disgraceful backdown. The commitment has been made in terms of the double dissolution. It is going to be stuck to and we are going to go through with it with great firmness. I believe that that is the correct constitutional procedure. I am surprised that conservative senators opposite now want to start fiddling around, bending and misinterpreting a Constitution which overwhelmingly their forebears helped to write.

I now wish to turn to the question of civil liberties. I am very impressed with Senator Chris Puplick's great defence of civil liberties. One has to confess that Senator Puplick is in a difficult position. He is one of the dying few small `l' liberals left in the Liberal Party of Australia. There must be only a very few of them left. He is very fortunate that he is able to stand up-I accept his integrity on this in that he has adopted a long-standing position on civil liberties-and, as my colleague Senator Aulich has said, give an almost classic, Shakespearian performance in defence of civil liberties. He is able to be in coalition with people like Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen and other members of the National Party from Queensland. He therefore performs with great conviction, with the support of all the conservatives in the coalition parties in this chamber.

However, before Senator Puplick gets too carried away about civil liberties, I think that there is a wider aspect of civil liberties that we in the labour movement always have to consider. I, like everybody else on this side of the chamber, fully support the right of individual freedoms as laid down in the Human Rights Charter of the United Nations. We in the Labor Party have been committed to those principles ever since we were founded in 1891 and they are enshrined in our national platform. But also enshrined in our national platform is the belief that civil liberties deal not just with political civil liberties and political freedoms. We as a democratic socialist party are committed to redistribution of wealth and the creation of a more equitable society. One way that has to be done is to ensure that the tax and revenue system of this country is fairly operated on behalf of all the people. There is no doubt that in many tax and social welfare areas there is fraud at the moment. Nobody has denied that. In fact, Senator MacGibbon has just given a most horrifying account of criminal activity, mentioning the Mafia and so on in terms of what is going on in this country; yet Opposition senators propose nothing to overcome those problems in our society, if they are as horrific as he described. He said that the Australia Card will not fix it, but if the Australia Card will not fix it, what will? Let us hear from Senator MacGibbon and Senator Haines what will fix these things.

The Australia Card will do a number of things when people have to carry out some transactions in their daily lives. It is said that the Australia Card will be intrusive and an annoyance and that ordinary people will always have to use it. The question is: how often will people have to produce the Australia Card? Apart from Medicare transactions for which they now have to produce their Medicare card, ordinary people will probably have to use the card once or twice a year. I am referring to ordinary citizens, the bulk of whom the Australian Labor Party is proud to represent. The reason many honourable senators opposite are opposed to the card is that it will have to be used when they want to carry out a range of transactions which the ordinary Australian never will have to carry out, or may have to carry out only once or twice in their lifetime.

How many ordinary Australians make their living out of buying and selling real estate? Not very many. Average Australians may buy or sell a house only once or twice in their lifetime, but an Australia Card will be used in carrying out real estate transactions. Of course the National Party in Queensland is totally opposed to an Australia Card having some sort of effect over such transactions. Mike Gore and the white shoe brigade on the Gold Coast, the property developers, would be the last people who would want some sort of honest record kept of their transactions. Mike Gore made the offer to raise $20m in the Bjelke-Petersen-for-Prime Minister campaign. Apparently Mike Gore raised only about $2m. Even some of the white shoe brigade realised that the Premier of Queensland in his political campaign was a sinking sun in the desert.

The next category involves sending funds overseas. How many ordinary Australians are in the business of sending funds overseas every day of their lives? Not too many that I know. Somebody like John Elliott probably does such things once a week, or once a day. Perhaps that is why John Elliott made the extraordinary statement the other day that there should be an Australia Card only for those people who apply for social welfare benefits-not for people like John Elliott who are into financial transactions overseas, probably into property investment, and probably into earning income for their companies or privately receiving rental income. No wonder he wants the card only for the poor and for those who rely on social security benefits and not for himself, because he will be affected and his companies may then have to start paying their fair share of tax.

How many ordinary Australians receive income from investment in shares and futures exchanges? I bet that barely 2 per cent of Australians would be in that category. Of course the Liberal and National parties-and, I am surprised, the Democrats-support them. Many supporters who pay the bills of the National Party and the Liberal Party receive income from share transactions and from future exchanges. Why should they not have a card to show that those transactions have been properly taxed and that the Australian community is receiving a fair percentage of the tax that should be paid to ensure equity in the tax system?

Another category is receiving payments from marketing authorities or produce agents. I suppose one has now found a reason why the National Party is also opposed to the card. It will mean that large graziers may have to show, on the occasions when they receive income from the Grain Marketing Authority or the Wool Authority, that the money has been properly paid to the person identified. I do not think that is a great imposition on many average family farmers whom the National Party purports to represent. I must say that these days the National Party seems to have been taken over by retired Treasury bureaucrats, multimillionaires and large graziers. The days when it represented small family farmers have long since gone.

An occasion on which ordinary Australians will have to use the Australia Card is in opening a new bank account. Again, I do not expect it will be that often, and most Australians will accept that as a reasonable proposition. It will also apply when applying for Commonwealth benefits, including Medicare and social security. In my view, no one, not even recipients of benefits, would think it unreasonable, in ensuring that the system is properly protected, that they should produce an Australia Card. In examining who has to produce the card we see the main reason why the Opposition parties are opposing it: the people who support them have something to lose. If we are talking about civil liberties, we must consider not only civil liberties in the political area but the economic civil liberties of the ordinary taxpayer and citizen who is being ripped off because rich people, people who support the Liberal and National parties, have had an unlimited go to duck and avoid paying their fair share of tax.

Senator MacGibbon mentioned the security of the dedicated landlines that would be used by the Australia Card service when it is introduced. He made some outrageous accusations in respect of the Australia Card that anybody could get into the telephone lines, that the system would be totally insecure, and therefore that information held within the system would be available to anybody who attempted to get into it. Since those remarks were made I have received some information which I should like to put on the record. The matter should be cleared up now because people like Senator MacGibbon will continue their scaremonger campaign. (Quorum formed) I am most touched that once again Senator Walters has ensured that I have a larger audience to listen to my remarks.

I wish to put on the record some information about security of landlines. We in the Australian Labor Party and the Government reiterate that the Australia Card system will incorporate the very best security and safeguards that we can provide and that it is impossible for all practical purposes to tap or hack into that system. The Australia Card information will be sent on dedicated landlines. Those lines simply cannot be tapped into through the telephone system or by hacking. As my colleague the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) stated yesterday, individual dedicated users of landlines simply cannot tap into any other information carried on the Australian landline system. It would be acutely difficult to identify the particular line or part of a line being used for transmission of Australia Card data. I challenge the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Tuckey, to give any example where a landline has been successfully tapped.

In addition to this layer of security the material on the Australia Card system will be encrypted, compressed and segmented. Nobody trying to read that information, even if it were available, would be able to make any sense of it at all. Nobody trying to read that information would be able to tap into the Australia Card Register and obtain any other information. And, of course, the Register itself will contain only the most basic identifying information. We regret the fact that the Opposition has chosen to misunderstand and misrepresent this position. We reiterate the Government's firm and clear statement that the information carried on the Australia Card system cannot be tapped, cannot be hacked, cannot be intercepted and cannot be understood or read by anyone except the personnel within the system itself. I trust that puts the position so clearly that even Senator MacGibbon can understand it.

In conclusion, I reiterate that I believe the introduction of the Australia Card will be one of the great reforms of the third term of the Hawke Labor Government. I think that in the next five or six years when it is operating, people will wonder what all the argument was about. I am sure that in the future people will look back at this time and realise that those who opposed the introduction of the Australia Card overwhelmingly were doing so because they had particular vested interests to protect. It is not the first time, unfortunately, that the Opposition parties in this country have been more interested in protecting vested and privileged interests which they represent at the expense of the Australian people. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Australia Card, both in this place and in the wider community, has been characterised by hyperbole, exaggerated statements and sheer nonsense. That has come from both sides of the debate. The last speaker for the Government, Senator Schacht, made it very clear where most of the absurd statements started. Very early on the Government decided to characterise everybody who was opposed to the Australia Card as a friend of tax cheats or social security fraud operators. Once that was the point at which the debate started it managed to go downhill from there. With the Australia Card, as with most other issues of dispute within our community, there is not only an idiotic rat bag debate; there is also a sensible debate. The proposal is far reaching and it will have reverberations, both through the legal system and through many other parts of government operations in Australia. As such it deserves close scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: If at the end of the day one could be assured that the card would fulfil some of the functions that have been claimed for it, one might give it closer attention. I believe that there are substantial major problems with the proposal, not the least of which is the inability of the Government so far in the only inquiry that has taken place with regard to the Australia Card actually to give a factual underpinning for the various claims that have been made. That neglect at that first inquiry has really bedevilled the debate since then. We have a proposal, the major ingredients of which are not only to combat crime and fraud on the Commonwealth revenue but also to link together all types of information.

One cannot get an argument going in addressing crime unless one believes that there will be a linkage of information and data. That is an essential ingredient of the card. That linkage of data will be held by government. There are a lot of people around the world who regard governments-quite rightly-with some suspicion, regardless of whether those governments are democratically elected. As parliamentarians we are all aware of the abuse of power by government and by bureaucrats with regard to individual citizens. I say all of us because I think anybody who has been a senator for even a short time would have had constituents come to him with examples of obvious abuses of power. That has been finally accepted over time by the Government because by looking at the Commonwealth Government and the Commonwealth bureaucracy we see that we have put in place a whole panoply of committees and appeals systems to protect citizens because of the abuse of power. We would not need those if that abuse did not take place.

Through the Australia Card we are now providing another area of possible abuse. That has to be accepted because we cannot argue that we must use this concentration of data to combat crime without also recognising that we are opening ourselves up to a very large area of possible further abuse of citizens' rights. It is a necessary corollary of any such move. I refer those senators who do not believe me to the debate that took place here when there was unanimous support for the establishment of the National Crime Authority. Whilst speaking in support of this Authority everybody spoke about our worry about intrusions into civil liberties. Whether the Government likes it or not there is a considerably body of opinion in Australia which is concerned about that. To simply say that all those people are friends of tax cheats manages to get the debate heading in exactly the opposite direction.

I raise some problems by reference to clause 14 of the Bill in which we find the relevant laws which can be accessed in relation to the Australia Card. These include the Social Security Act, the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act, the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act, the Student Assistance Act, the Australian Citizenship Act, the Passport Act and the Migration Act. They are all areas where information can be obtained through the system. It is eligible information under the definition provided in the Bill. That is obviously one area in which some Government senators may at least have resonated in their younger days-I certainly did-in terms of the opposition to the Vietnam war, if they happened to have been students. This is accessible information. The digitised photographs fairly obviously will be able to identify those types of people. I suggest that the effectiveness of the moratorium campaigns would have been destroyed by this method had the Australia Card been in existence at that time. I am not trying to draw a long bow. The exercise is perfectly feasible. In fact in Queensland the Special Branch had a jolly good attempt at this with cameras. But, of course, the televising and digitising of photographs gives instant information and name and address, which is something that even the Special Branch in Queensland sometimes finds it difficult to obtain-at least, directly.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you fool them by wearing beards.

—If one shaves one's beard off and then grows it again, it works wonders. In the situation to which I refer the last major mass demonstration against Government policy in this country would have been effectively undermined and destroyed. I used that example because I hoped to appeal at least to some people in the Government ranks who may have been involved in that exercise. I am not sure how many of them were involved; possibly more members of the Opposition than members of the Government were involved. That is an example of why people have a legitimate concern about the power of government to identify and quantify information in the manner allowed under the provisions of the Australia Card Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a fair amount of debate in the community and elsewhere about thin ends of wedges. I must admit that I am not terribly happy with that form of argument because I think it partly represents the conspiracy argument, which is not at the best of times a very strong one. However, in this case there is a very legitimate problem. I will raise an instance in which I was involved over this very card, when the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform was looking at the problem of cleansing the electoral rolls. We were very much aware of the reluctance of any government-I am sure that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, has been involved in such discussions in Cabinet-to spend money on the cleansing of our electoral rolls. It is an expensive, time-consuming operation. One has to employ lots of people who have to knock on doors and do a lot of checking. In the Committee we addressed ourselves to the question of what we would recommend if the Australia Card became law. On the basis of efficiency alone, one could not argue for continuing the labour intensive operations that we have had to date with expenditure of some $15m to $20m a year on getting our electoral rolls up to date when it could be done by pressing a button. So what one would have to argue is whether, if the Australia Card were in place, we ought to allow the electoral rolls to go under it, for that very reason of pure efficiency. If one looks at almost every area of government one finds corresponding instances. It is inevitable that once this legislation is passed it will be extended, extended and extended. There is no way to prevent that. There would be no reason to prevent it, in effect, because of the efficiency argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Humphreys has already wanted it.

—I am saying that because of efficiency we would be faced with saving $15m in this area. As we would already have the stuff collected, why not include that? One could raise another $20m in another area, another $30m elsewhere. In other words, the areas of saving would start to steamroll. The incremental creep of this would inevitably go on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pure baloney and hogwash to say that what is in the legislation is what we are addressing; it is not and it cannot be. Anybody who is in government knows that. I am not just talking about the current Labor Government. I doubt whether conservative governments once in power, although I understand that the Opposition parties have said that they would do so, would repeal the legislation. Once an executive government had such legislation in place, it would love it. That is the major problem. Regardless of what a parliamentary party might like, executive governments would like this because it would give them an unending source of revenue because they could keep eliminating additional functions down the line.

We are looking at a major change. We are not just looking at what is already in the legislation. We are looking at turning around the whole system of government surveillance of citizens. I use the word `surveillance' advisedly because governments already engage in surveillance of citizens. For example, we have had some very interesting debates in this place about the tapping of the telephone lines. A number of people, including me, have argued to keep State governments out of such an exercise. I do not trust even a Federal government with such an exercise, and I certainly would not trust State governments with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them.

—Well, it is abused at the Federal level anyway, and it would be more vastly abused if more governments were involved. It is one of the inevitable consequences of the way governments operate. So surveillance already takes place, and it will be extended. Already in my State we have instances of false information being given. Almost every week-certainly every month-one can read a horror story about some poor person being bailed up in his own home by the drug squad or somebody else and whose home has been ransacked and the doors broken down. As happened in the last instance, it often turns out to be the wrong street. In the last instance the police had the right number but were in the wrong street. So misinformation held by government in this country-probably one of the most democratic countries on earth-is sometimes used violently to abuse the civil liberties of our citizens. In fact, we now have Acts in every State and the Commonwealth which provide monetary recompense because we know that at some stage governments will abuse the liberties of citizens. We allow people some kind of monetary recompense for being woken up in the middle of the night and having a shotgun pointed at them, as happened to the poor citizens in the last drug raid that went wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now to have a computerised operation. One government senator said that with a wave of a hand any citizen will be able to look at his record. I presume that that honourable senator has not actually read the legislation. Access to one's record will be allowed once a year. But the type of information on record could ruin one within one year. Access to the record once a year is supposed somehow to recompense one for the possibility of having one's livelihood ruined along the way.

Quite frankly, what we are facing is a massive problem. There will be massive problems of abuse. There will be massive problems of leaks. I loved hearing a previous speaker say that he was so enamoured of the protection mechanisms that were to be built in that he actually believed them. Presumably he has never bothered to speak to anybody in the computer industry. We know that there will be leaks. For example, why is it that under the largest governmental system that we have at present the health records of Federal Ministers have a special lock on them? Why is there a special lock? It is for the very good reason that otherwise one could get access to them. So a special device exists to avoid any embarrassment to Federal Ministers. But people can get around most of these devices, through decoding, compressing, dedicated landlines, et cetera. I am not saying that such devices are not important. Of course they are. We know that there is vital information that needs to be protected and we do need a whole variety of measures to protect them. But at the end of the day we could have the problem that Canada had when somebody walked off with all of the tax records and they were not retrieved for a couple of weeks. At the end of the day the human element is always involved. I am not sure whether human beings are going to be eliminated from the system but provided they operate it, there will be security leaks. I do not even have to go to the arguments about dedicated landlines. Once human beings use the system we have the possibility of information being abused and at the end of the day the information that it is being abused may never come to the knowledge of the individual citizen.

Honourable senators know as well as I do that there are companies in capital cities which one can ring to get tax returns. Honourable senators throw up their hands and deny all knowledge of this when outside this chamber but they all know about it. They know that they can get a security check on an individual if they really have to and that people have used those systems and have told senators about them. In other words, Australia's most secure system, which is our taxation system, is abused every day of the week. At the end of the day there is not a protection which will beat human beings.

Are we now going to accept that we will make available much more generally and in a compressed form a whole variety of pieces of information? What is that information? It is the person's name, address and date of birth. Of course the Australia Card Register will contain other information. I have already gone through the various Acts from which information can be drawn but on top of that information can be obtained on a person's eligibility to receive Medicare benefits, a record of eligibility to obtain employment, any name used by the person, previous residential and postal addresses, a list of documents used to establish identity, the person's Australia Card number and information from government departments which come under the various Acts I have mentioned. This may include, for example, information held by the Commissioner of Taxation and information held by a department acquired for purposes connected with the administration of laws such as student allowances, and there is a fairly large amount of information there, not only on the individual but also on the individual's parents and the individual's siblings. The Register will contain information held on personnel records of members of the defence forces. If honourable senators have actually ever seen records on members of the defence forces they will know that there is not much that the defence forces do not end up knowing about a member, and about his grandmother as well. So at the end of the day one would have a fairly healthy grasp of that person and his connections with other people in the community. This is why the Government is talking about the fight on crime, and I will come to that in a moment. This type of information could be seen to be very useful in that regard.

Of course the matter goes beyond that because a number of the sub-sets of that type of information would lead us to know where the person spends his holidays and where he spends money. In fact, some of those sub-sets could even turn up information such as the periodicals to which a person subscribes. The value of that information on the commercial market is absolutely incalculable and that is why I am saying that there will be leaks. This Bill will provide a whole new area of crime. We are generating a whole new area of crime by the mere bringing in of this Bill. Undoubtedly, we will have what is one of the major industries in Mexico City-a card forging industry. One can get one's United States security number in Mexico City. Everyone knows about the shops there that provide the cards; in fact there are shops just off the main street that do so. I am not quite sure whether we will have shopfronts in Australia that will provide them but obviously the operation will occur here.

The exercise is fraught with massive problems. I do not think we have to rely simply on the assertions made in Australia; we can look at some of the operations in other countries. For example, in recent times the former Chairman of the Swedish Data Protection Board has resigned for the very reason that he felt that privacy is no longer adequately protected. We know that the proposed Data Protection Agency in the Australia Card Bill is modelled on the Swedish Board. The Swedish Data Protection Board up to recent times was considered-it probably still is-to be the best security that has been offered by any country with regard to data. Yet its Chairman resigned because he says that privacy can no longer adequately be protected. One has to pause under those circumstances and not dismiss them as though they are the ravings of lunatics. So many people in the community have massive concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —What follows from all of that? Are the Swedes going to abandon their system?

—Our Agency is based on the Swedish one. In fact it has not even improved on it; it is deficient when compared with it. Yet the Chairman of the Swedish Board-presumably he is in a position to know-thinks the Swedish system is no longer adequately able to protect the privacy of Swedish citizens. Let us be assured that the privacy of Australians will not be protected. It just will not happen. With all the good will in the world that may be there, by the Government and the bureaucrats, privacy will not be protected. I do not think we have to go to conspiracy theories about this matter. It is a fact: that is what will occur.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very doubtful of what will be achieved with this card at the end of the day. I do not think by and large that the types of crimes we are facing in Australia will be inhibited all that much. As I have already said, fraud and forgery of cards will be a problem. After all, the ID cards in Europe do not seem to do too much. Honourable senators who are familiar with Italy would know that not terribly much happened to its underground economy or organised crime with the introduction of a card after the Second World War.

The Department of Social Security does not believe that social security fraud will be reduced because most lost revenue results from the failure of people to notify their changed circumstances, not from forged identities. A presumption of validity will be attached to the card whether or not it has been obtained legally, hence opening up a whole new area of possible crime. The card itself will be used to commit crimes, and that is fairly obvious. If honourable senators do not believe that, they should look at all of the other cards that are operating in society and they would see the types of crimes that occur by the mere existence of the card.

This card will be very important because it will be presumed to be valid. The difficulty is that it will be presumed that if a person's photograph is on it, that is that person and it is his card. Hence, it will be used for all sorts of purposes not the least of which is possibly getting into the new Parliament House.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least the automatic teller machines won't chew them up.

—I am not at all sure that a little down the way, this Government will not find a very good way to use the Australia Card and that is to turn it into a smart card and sell part of it off to private enterprise. It seems to be wanting to privatise most other things and that would certainly be a very lucrative area. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who has just come into the chamber, is probably already looking at this area.
