The tax file number alternative recommended by the majority of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card would certainly tackle these types of problems, more cheaply and without the threat to civil liberties.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are facing is an inexorable movement possibly towards a joint sitting to which I will refer in conclusion. There has been some discussion of mandates and otherwise in regard to this matter. I think the situation is relatively clear. Those senators who campaigned to oppose the card were returned in an increased majority in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except most of them didn't campaign.

—Be that as it may, I am talking for myself. I certainly made quite a number of speeches, as Senator Jones, who is in the chamber at the moment, can attest to. I certainly campaigned on the matter. It is an absurd notion of parliamentary democracy to say that, although one of the issues I campaigned on was this issue, and presumably some people voted for me on that basis, because people also voted for the Government on the basis of its campaign, I should now agree with them. I and other senators who are opposing this card have to stay true to the people who voted for us. We have to continue the opposition to this card to the death knell. All talk to the contrary is by the by. If the Government had done so well that it had got the majority in this place, there would not even be a debate going on now, for obvious reasons. The fact that the Government did not get the majority in this chamber means that the debate will continue through to a joint sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: I express my support for the inquiry because I believe that, as more people come to know about the problems associated with the card, more will become concerned. I am referring to people who are conscientious enough to read the Bill and to attempt to understand its provisions. I am referring not to people who will oppose almost anything-the people whom one just tells to oppose something and who do-but to the very large number of people in the community who have genuine concerns and who have read the Bill. It is remarkable how many photostat copies of the Bill, because one cannot get hold of originals, are floating around in the community. The number of photostat copies I have come across at meetings is enormous. People have gone to the trouble of reading through the Bill, and it has been an educative task for many of them. These people have genuine concerns and should not be dismissed by the Government in the way that they have been to date.

The Government arrogantly says that it will at some stage amend the Bill but will not even tell us how it is to amend it. We are buying a pig in a poke. We are being asked to pass a Bill which the Government has declared it is its intention to amend. If that is not holding this Parliament in contempt, I do not know what is. The Government is saying, `Please pass this Bill although we know it is defective'. That is an absurd way to proceed. Under the Constitution the Government can propose amendments which can be discussed in a joint sitting. So that argument cannot be used as an excuse.

As this issue progresses the community will become more and more educated. The political imperative for the Government is to try to get the matter over and done with as quickly as it can because it is facing elections in States where I am sure it does not want this issue on the agenda and it knows that it is becoming increasingly unpopular as a result. I ask the Government to reconsider its position and to consider the alternatives which are available to achieve the same goals of overcoming tax fraud and welfare cheats.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an old political tactic, perfected by the Australian Labor Party, when one is in a tight corner, to use intimidation, to attack personally, and to come out fighting, because that is the best means of defence. Try to stop public debate; make sure that the public stay ill-informed-that is the only way one can win the race. That is exactly what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been doing. We all know the statement he has been making-that only those who have something to fear will worry about an ID card. Barrie Unsworth, trying to cover himself because an election is coming up, is saying, `Have a rethink, Mr Hawke. An election is close on my heels'. John White from Tasmania, a good Labor bloke, stood on the same platform as me and said, `The Labor Party is wrong and must withdraw'.

SPEECH.PARA: We had the Labor Lawyers Association-a good crowd-opposing the Labor Party. The Trades and Labor Council is also opposing the Labor Party. Jim McClelland is saying that Labor is wrong. Ben Lexcen, who was Bob Hawke's best friend when he won the America's Cup-`me mate Ben'; he was a mate then-is now, apparently, a taxation cheat. Alan Jones, often spoken of in the same breath as Ben Lexcen, is also supposedly a taxation cheat. And what about Peter Garrett? Apparently he is also a taxation cheat. What did the Minister call that mob yesterday? The Minister called them a motley crew. I wonder what Barrie Unsworth thinks about being called a motley crew. I wonder what John White thinks about it. Now-the latest one-Peter Duncan has been added to the motley crew. A headline in the newspaper today reads, `New Minister contradicts Mr Hawke on the card'. But I will come to that in a little while.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ought to read it.

—I read it. Labor people, Mr Hawke in particular, have been telling us that they had a mandate, although there was not a word about it in Mr Hawke's election speech. I was censored in Tasmania on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) when I went forward with a leaked document. I did a very good interview. I complained to the ABC. When the ABC refused to put on my interview I rang the ABC and said to Phil Martin: `Okay, Phil, was it because it was too hot for the Labor Party that the ABC would not put it on?' He said, `All I can say, Shirley, is that direction came from Sydney that it was not to go to air'. How do honourable senators like that?
—Who said that? Name the person.

—Phil Martin, of the ABC. After the election I rang Phil and said, `Okay, is it safe enough now? Labor is back. Will you now have me on the ABC?' He said, `I will get you on the 7.30 Report'. So I did another interview for the 7.30 Report on the same subject. When I was asked why I did not take a higher profile during the election campaign I said, `Because you censored me. Before the elections I was up here and did an interview. It was not shown. Phil Martin said that direction had come from Sydney that the interview was not to go to air'. What happened? The producer of the 7.30 Report came down and said, `I am sorry, but that cannot go to air'. Then what happened? Phil Wallington from The World Today rang me and asked me a question on the Australia Card. When he asked me why I did not take a high profile during the election campaign I answered: `Because you, the ABC, censored me'. I said to him, `You ask Phil Martin what he said to me, because he said to me, ``Direction came from Sydney that it was not to go to air'' '. When Phil Martin was asked about that, what did he say? He said, `Oh, no; Senator Walters got it wrong. It was just that Sydney was not interested'. But the words that Phil Martin used to me were not `Sydney was not interested'; they were, `Sydney said that it was not to go to air'. Honourable senators opposite ask us why we did not have a high profile. We did not have a high profile because we were censored.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has made lots of claims about this ID card. But the speech of the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) yesterday was thoroughly untrue. There were so many untruths in that speech that she ought to be ashamed of herself. The Government said that the card would be effective in dealing with tax evasion, social security fraud and crime. It said that it would be cost-effective and, of course, it said that all the privacy in the world would be very, very secure. Let us deal with tax evasion. If honourable senators opposite have read the Auditor-General's report on the taxing problem they might agree with the Prime Minister, who has no doubt read that report, when he said to the Australian Taxation Office, `Tighten yourself up'. What has happened? Twelve months after that report came out the Taxation Office has indeed tightened up. It found that 90,000 taxpayers had been cheating to the tune of $770m-all without the ID card. It was just the will of the Taxation Office after the Prime Minister had told it to tighten up. There was no need for an ID card. An amount of $770m was collected from 90,000 taxpayers because the Prime Minister said so.

Let us look at social security fraud. When I asked a question at an Estimates committee hearing, the Department of Social Security told me that an ID card would not help it at all and that it was not identification that was its problem but mis-statements. So the Department has assured us that the ID card would be no help. What has the Prime Minister done about that problem? He demanded that all those getting unemployment benefits be reviewed. What was the result of that? A quarter of them were found to be collecting unemployment benefits when they should not have been. No ID card was necessary and no ID card was used; it was just the will of the Department to get stuck into its job, as was demanded of it by the Prime Minister. That deals with the social security fraud.

Let us look at crime. The Prime Minister says that the Australia Card will fix crime. Mr Costigan and the Australian Federal Police have said that it will not touch big crime. Big crime will quickly have its ID cards forged and when these criminals forge these cards they will be accepted without question as the individual they claim to be. They can take on an assumed identity once they produce a forged ID card. They can have a whole handful of cards, and they can assume the identities of the various names on them, with no question at all. The young people in Kings Cross already have forged drivers licences, photograph and all, so that they can use them in the pubs to say that they are old enough to drink there.

Let us look at the privacy laws which Mr Hawke tells us are so secure. I would first like to read to honourable senators what the Minister in charge, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), believes about the need for privacy in this country. Dr Blewett said at a branch conference of the Australian Labor Party in South Australia:

Let me say as a socialist that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right . . . We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

There is a deadly hush from the socialist Government opposite because Dr Blewett makes it very clear that his view is that socialists should not get too hung up on privacy, because privacy is `a bourgeois . . . very much associated with . . . private property'. That is what this Government thinks about the need to protect the privacy of Australian people. Do not give me the Prime Minister's comments that he will make sure that privacy is maintained. Privacy cannot be maintained. There is no desire on the part of the Minister that it be maintained. Of course, it is a lot of rubbish.

We have already had security leaks from that Minister's Department. We have already had the leaking to the police of the names of young girls who had had abortions and their being dragged into court for having abortions performed by a doctor. That is from the Department of the Minister that the Government has placed in charge of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to debate that? That was not a leak.

—That was leaked by him. Other leaks from that Department involved doctors' incomes, and we had Government senators saying in this chamber this morning, `And what is wrong with that?'. That is another instance of the socialist attitude that privacy is not important. Senator Schacht said today: `What is wrong with that? What have the doctors to hide?'-another indication of the lack of even the faintest understanding on the part of the socialist group opposite of what privacy is all about. Through public servants, current information, including addresses of social security recipients, has been sold to debt collectors. How is that for security?

SPEECH.PARA: Yet this Prime Minister assures us that we will have every security under the sun and that, if we do not, he will introduce amendments to require such security. Let us see. We now have a couple of Ministers for transport. We have a maxi-Minister in this place, whom Senator Schacht quoted. Let me quote the mini-Minister in the place opposite. The Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, Mr Duncan, said that it would be possible to `physically' tap into the proposed ID card system. This is what I am saying. Peter Duncan, the mini- Minister for land transport, the man in charge of the landlines about which we have heard our maxi-Minister speak so much, says that that is all rubbish and that, indeed, it is physically possible to tap in. He said:
Dedicated data systems can still be compromised by someone physically tapping into an exchange or transmission line.

So, we have the mini-Minister in the other chamber assuring us that what the Prime Minister and the maxi-Minister say is totally wrong-and of course he is right, because it is only the members of the Left in this place who are at the moment telling the truth about the ID card.

The computer experts in this country also agree. They say that there is no way privacy can be maintained. Indeed, we have had the situation-odd as it may be-of hackers getting into the Pentagon. Another release just recently says that young West German hackers have had access to the United States National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The hackers got into that, and the Government tells us that our data will all be private and so secure.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they going to do with your name and address when they have got it?
—There we are. Here we go again. There is no need for privacy; it does not really matter if they get in!
—I don't care who has mine.

—There we are. The honourable senators says: `I don't care, so why should anyone else care?'. In the case of the doctors' incomes dispute, which was investigated by the Australian Federal Police, only a handful of public servants were meant to have access to that information. What did the police find? They found that 197 public servants had access to it. Of course every public servant who wants to have access to the three computers will have access. Senator Ryan says that there will be nothing sensitive on the ID card and nothing sensitive on the Register. But there will be a number, and once the number typed up on the three computers of those three departments, and those computers, to use the jargon, talk to each other, there will be a mass of information about every individual. The whole history of what is on their medical files, their social security files and what financial transactions they have carried out will be there. There will be a wealth of information to be abused by anyone who wants to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan said yesterday that there is no need for a central data base. Of course there is not, because the number on the card and on the Register will enable anyone with access to those three computers that talk to each other to gain any information.

I turn to deal with just how this passing of information can be increased. I have a document from the Health Insurance Commission. It contains the recommendations of the Commission to the interdepartmental committee, chaired by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, about how the system should be set up. It says in part:

It will be important to minimise any adverse public reaction to implementation of the system. One possibility would be to use a staged approach for implementation, whereby only less sensitive data are held in the system initially with the facility to input additional data at a later stage when public acceptance may be forthcoming more readily.
Other related issues . . . are the extent to which:
(a) the nature of all items of data held on the central database will be made known to the public;

Are we going to tell people everything? The document also asks whether the names of the government agencies with access to the system will be made public and what non-government agencies will be permitted access to the system. Apart from those recommendations to the interdepartmental committee, chaired by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, we have had other leaks from public servants who are very concerned and who are becoming more and more concerned about this. A newspaper article referred to a `Discussion Paper on Recording Changes to Data on the Australia Card Registry', and said that, in part, the paper stated:
In respect of programme management information, changes may be made to the register without the need of any notification to the card subject.

The article quotes a Mr Robertson as saying that he believed there would be an open file containing information that people would know about, because they have given that information, and that there would be a second file that people would not be allowed to see that would contain more detailed information. Of course more information has been leaked on the hacker's handbook of how to get into the system. So we are now getting information from public servants who are becoming very concerned about just what is happening with these things. Honourable senators must not forget that the Labor Party normally caucuses its members very strictly. But in Tasmania recently the Labor Party Secretary, Mr Eugene Alexander, is quoted as saying:
. . . the party had to be broadminded over the issue, as it was obvious a number of members had widely differing views.

The Party in Tasmania was not going to get stuck into its members. It just said that they had widely differing views on the ID card and that there would be no criticism of them. The President of the Labor Party, Mr Leo Brown, is quoted as saying:
Members are free to discuss the issue and that's their democratic right.

That is the first bit of democracy that we have heard about in the Labor Party-that it is members' democratic right to oppose the Party, because it says, `At present support for the Australia Card is not ALP State policy, nor is it Federal policy'. Members can be disciplined only for breaking policy or for attacking the Party. The Tasmanian Labor Party, which is pretty Left too, has decided to let its members have free rein. John White can stand up on the same platform with me and say, `The Labor Party is wrong and it is introducing something that is really quite a disgrace'.

We have been told that because so many problems with privacy have been pointed out to the Government the Bill needs amending. The Government is prepared to put a flawed Bill through the Senate, knowing that it needs amending. What a disgrace that is. It will not tell us what those amendments are likely to be. Let the Minister take on notice that the Government can put nothing through this Parliament because it has not got the numbers. It does not matter what it attempts to put through by way of amendments; it has not got the numbers. The Government says the card will be most cost-effective. There are 2,150 new public servants just for starters to keep an eye on the public. According to the Government's own figures, it will cost $759m over 10 years. What will the cost be to private industry? The Government has done the work but it will not allow us to see the information. Private industry sources tell us that their estimate is that it will cost $800m to $1 billion. We tried very hard to get that information through the freedom of information legislation and we were knocked back, but I believe that the Government came up with a fictitious figure which it gave Mr Porter some time within the last couple of months.

The banks have already explained to the Government that they will not be able to use their automatic teller machines-those machines which people put cards into and get money from. The banks now say that the machines cannot be used and the Government has said, `Don't worry; we will amend the Bill'. The Government is putting through an imperfect Bill and telling us that it will amend it later.

Senator Schacht said today that there are only two things that an ordinary person will have to do in relation to the card. He said that the card would have to be produced to open a new bank account and to collect the Medicare benefit. That is untrue. The ordinary Australian will not use a card only to open a new bank account. He will have to use the card to operate an existing account. I asked the senator in charge of this Bill in this place, Senator Ryan, the day before yesterday in the Senate: What happens straight after the card comes in? What happens to all the cheques floating around? How does anyone know that the cheques he receives are going to be honoured; because the person may not have presented his ID card to the bank? She said, `Yes, that is true. Some people may take some time to do that, and if they do, their account will continue to accrue interest, and will in every other way be of benefit to them'.-except of course that they cannot use it. They cannot draw on it. That is what the Minister said. What a wonderful benefit!

It is a pity that Senator Schacht does not do a bit more homework. He is pretty new and he probably has not done a lot of work on the ID card. If he has not, he should not be pushed up here by the Government just because it is finding it hard to get senators to speak on this Bill. It should not pick on the new fellows who do not know that the Government is telling a lot of untruths. The Government is pushing them up. We have got three new fellows speaking on this because none of the old ones will take the floor on it. We had Senator Schacht standing on his feet not knowing about the Bill and not telling the truth about it. He told the people out there that the only occasions on which they will have to produce the card are when they collect their Medicare benefits or open new bank accounts. What they will have to do, of course, is present the card to their employer. They will have to present it if they want to use their present bank account. Of course, they will have to use it to open a new account or collect their Medicare entitlements. They will also have to use it if they want to buy or sell a block of land or a house. They will have to use it if they pay rent. There are a whole host of reasons why they will have to use the card. Is it not a pity that poor Senator Schacht does not understand the Bill and that the Government has put him on his feet to speak in order to fill the numbers. Senator Ryan said something yesterday which is a complete untruth. She said:

The Bill is also quite specific that no one-not the police, not the local supermarket, not the local publican-can ask to see one's card as a means of identification. Any unauthorised person asking for a person's card, or even suggesting-
she elaborates-
he wants to see it, is committing a serious offence punishable by a heavy fine or gaol or both.

That is simply not true. Indeed, I will quote from the Bill because I think it is pretty important that the people, who I might add cannot get a copy of the Bill, should know what is in it. Even if there are some copies of the Bill in the Government Printing Office, people will not be able to afford to buy them. I have been told in Hobart that hundreds of people have tried to get a copy of the Bill in that city. They have been told that the cost of the Bill, which is not accompanied by an explanatory memorandum, is $14.40. Although there is a supplementary memorandum, the main one is not available. What would one expect an ordinary man in the street to learn from the Bill if it was not accompanied by an explanatory memorandum? A person has to pay $14.40 for the Bill and $3.70 for the supplementary memorandum. The cost of the legislation works out to be over 11c a page whereas the Income Tax Assessment Act costs 3.6c a page.

What is the Government trying to do in hiding the Bill? How can we expect Joe Blow to walk into a Government Printing Office outlet and pay $14.40 just for the Bill? What on earth is the Government on about? Of course it is trying to hide the situation. Let me get back to the claim by Senator Ryan that people cannot be asked for the card. She is not speaking the truth when she says that because the Bill says:
Except as authorised by this Act, a person shall not require another person to produce a Card.

The legislation refers to production of the card being required, not demanded. Everyone in this chamber knows that if a policeman on a corner says to a young bloke, `Where is your ID card? I think you are looking suspicious', and the recipient says, `You cannot demand my card of me', the policeman will say, `I am not demanding it, sonny, I am asking you for it'. If the chap says, `I am not going to give it to you', the policeman will use Bob Hawke's intimidatory language and will say, `and what have you got to hide?' Do not, for heaven's sake, think for one moment that this card will not become a common identifier, because it will. There is no doubt at all about that.
I would like to wind up with a quote. Unfortunately my time is just about up. Let us look at what was said by Woodrow Wilson. I think it is pretty impressive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was he?
—The socialists opposite do not even know who he is, but it was he who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Liberty has never come from government. Liberty has always come from the subjects of it. The history of liberty is a history of resistance. The history of liberty is a history of limitations of governmental power, not the increase of it.

How true those statements are. We will not tolerate and we will not have an ID card in this country. We are not going the way of Nazi Germany or the socialist mates in Moscow of honourable senators opposite. The Australian people will not tolerate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for the third time to support the Australia Card Bill brought before this Parliament by the Hawke Government. For the third time the Government has introduced the Australia Card legislation into the Senate. The Senate has rejected the legislation on two previous occasions. The second refusal on 2 April triggered a double dissolution of the Australian Parliament and the subsequent election on 11 July. Let us be quite clear about this recent historical fact. The Australia Card was the only parliamentary or legislative issue which triggered the dissolution of Parliament on 5 June for the election on 11 July. It was the only parliamentary or legislative issue which triggered the dissolution of the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia. The July election was called in accordance with the due processes of the Australian Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed).

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interrupted by Senator Walters who is trying to stifle the democratic processes and debate in this Parliament of Australia. After speaking for half an hour about civil rights and civil liberties she is not prepared to cop it when it is dished out. Like other members of the Opposition, she is not prepared to receive it after she has given it and to take on the chin the arguments in favour of the Australia Card. Honourable senators opposite do not believe in free speech and free debate. They want to stifle this debate by the artifical calling of quorums.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was pointing out, the July election was called in accordance with the due processes of the Australian Constitution. But now, less than three months later, Opposition and Australian Democrats senators are claiming that somehow the Government does not have a mandate to proceed to a joint sitting of the Australian Parliament to decide the outcome of the Australia Card legislation. The very same senators exercised their legislative prerogative and twice rejected the Australia Card, thus triggering the double dissolution of the Australian Parliament. That is how we came to this position. They exercised their rights under the Constitution to block the Government's legislation. But now, with breathtaking effrontery, they claim that a joint sitting of the Australian Parliament, the constitutional process which resolves a deadlock between two Houses, is somehow a sleight of hand, and a petty trick called on by the democratically elected Government of this country. That is their attitude. They will not accept the umpire's verdict-it is as simple as that. The Opposition and the Democrats seem to believe that the Australian Constitution does not serve to protect the legal and political rights of all Australians but is there merely to serve their own self-interest and partisan political purposes.

In a nonsensical speech today, Senator MacGibbon, who I note is a senator from Queensland, waxed eloquent about civil rights and civil liberties. However, he is a senator from the very State where political rights are denied by a nineteenth-century gerrymander. This senator, from a political party which has squibbed the debate on democratic rights in Queensland, came into the Australian Senate today and lectured us about civil and political rights.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Ministers of State Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 received royal assent this morning. As honourable senators are aware, this legislation has increased the possible number of Ministers of State from 27 to 30. Following the granting of royal assent, His Excellency the Administrator at noon today at Government House appointed as Ministers of State the following honourable senators and members: Senator the Hon. Michael Carter Tate to be Minister of State for Justice and to administer the Attorney-General's Department; the Hon. Roslyn Joan Kelly, MP, to be Minister of State for Defence Science and Personnel and to administer the Department of Defence; and Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds to be Minister of State for Local Government and to administer the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Following his appointment as Minister, when did he first ask for and receive a detailed briefing from his Department on the coastal surveillance contract? Did the Minister consider the briefing adequate, and in particular was he satisfied with the contribution of the Australian Federal Police before and after the awarding of the contracts to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd? If not, what further matters did he raise with the Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My recollection is that the subject of the Amann contract came up in the initial few days of detailed briefing on current issues within the Department. It then came up again on several occasions during the early part of August, as I started asking more and more questions about what the probability was of the particular deadlines being reached and what contingency plans, if any, had been made to fill the vacuums that might arise from the first week of September until 12 December, after Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd phased out and Amann was scheduled to come in but might not be ready to do so. I am trying to recall the first time that the question of police and security issues arose. Naturally, I asked at an early stage of proceedings what, if anything, was on the record on the police aspects of it, not least because a number of allegations were being made in the public media at that stage about alleged interference by Skywest with Amann and reciprocal counter-allegations.

ANSWER.PARA: The statement I tabled this morning indicates Mr Beale's record of when he first responded to my request to bring me up to date on this. That was in his minute of 1 September, the relevant portion of which is set out in the papers I tabled this morning. There was some subsequent exchange between me and Mr Beale, as the statement indicates, on 7 September. I think that was the last time a security matter came in issue. It was perfectly clear to me, on the basis of the papers I saw, the briefing I received from Mr Beale of my Department and from the nature of that briefing that there was no security matter in issue, and that if the contract was to be terminated it would be on grounds having nothing whatsoever to do with police and security considerations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. However, he did not address himself at all to the question about the adequacy of the briefing that he received. Can he please tell us whether he was happy on all occasions of the various briefings he mentioned, including the briefing from the Australian Federal Police?

—I have no complaints, then or now, about the quality of the briefing I received from the Australian Federal Police, which was a briefing communicated both in the form of written minutes and orally through Mr Beale, the Associate Secretary of my Department.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Justice been drawn to the resignation on Wednesday night of the former Queensland Assistant Commissioner, Mr Graeme Parker, who subsequently admitted to the Fitzgerald commission of inquiry in Queensland that he was in fact corrupt. In view of Mr Parker's confession to the Fitzgerald inquiry, what measures does the National Crime Authority (NCA) have to protect witnesses who have already given evidence, and those who might be encouraged to do so in future, from harassment or even death from organised crime bodies now clearly being identified as operating within Australia? Will the National Crime Authority investigate the very serious allegations being raised in the Fitzgerald inquiry of widespread organised crime in Australia, and what steps are being taken to monitor the information coming forward day by day?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Jones for his question, which I know touches matters which are of great concern to him and to other Queensland senators in particular. He raises matters which are of grave concern to us all, because when it is revealed that corruption has taken hold at the very highest levels within our police force, naturally it fills ordinary citizens with foreboding. Given the fact that police officers naturally exercise quite considerable discretion in carrying out their duties, one needs to have a sense of the fairness and impartiality with which they will undertake those duties. The stench of corruption which is now being revealed in the Fitzgerald inquiry reaching to high levels gives cause for foreboding insofar as that trust in police forces is thereby undermined. The inquiry and its conduct by Mr Fitzgerald entirely vindicate statements that I made at the end of the last autumn session of Parliament, just before Parliament rose, where I expressed my confidence in the integrity and forcefulness with which Mr Fitzgerald would undertake his inquiries. There was some scepticism whether that would be the case, but I think that he is doing so.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to Senator Jones's particular questions, the fact is that the admissions made by Mr Parker have caused me concern not only in the general sense I have indicated, but because it is the case that Mr Parker, as Assistant Commissioner, was the liaison officer for the Queensland Police with the National Crime Authority. Mr Parker filled this role during 1986 and parts of this year before he took leave on account of his current illness. During that time Mr Parker attended three of the Authority's operations conferences, two in 1986, I think in February and July, and one in March 1987, in his capacity as Assistant Commissioner (Crime and Services). Quite clearly, without going into the matters discussed at the operations conferences, matters will have been discussed which explain the concern that I share with Senator Jones. In that respect the National Crime Authority is seeking to interview Mr Parker concerning matters of interest to it. I think at the moment the matter should be left there. I have had conversations with the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Justice Stewart, this morning and that is the situation which has been reached at this point.

Senator Jones raised the very proper concern about the protection of witnesses and those who might be sources of information-I take it that he means both to the Fitzgerald inquiry and to NCA and police inquiries-and how the NCA or the Federal Government might be involved in the protection of such witnesses. In the latter stages of the autumn session I pointed out to the Senate that the National Crime Authority had a reference which overlapped with many of the matters which are the subject of Mr Fitzgerald's inquiry. In fact, that was under a joint reference given by the Commonwealth Government and the Government of the State of Queensland. Insofar as that overlap means that many of the witnesses and sources of information available to Mr Fitzgerald are of equal interest and are providing information to the National Crime Authority, clearly the NCA in appropriate circumstances and where it makes an assessment that the protection of such persons is necessary, will undertake such measures.

Finally, Senator Jones asked what `tick tacking'- to use a colloquialism-is taking place between the NCA and the Fitzgerald inquiry. Again, at the end of the last autumn session I indicated to the Senate that I had asked the NCA-and this would have been forthcoming in any case-and the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to be as co-operative as possible with the Fitzgerald inquiry. I understand that Mr Fitzgerald has, on every occasion when he has sought the assistance of the NCA and the AFP, received that assistance in a timely and useful way. Naturally, the relationship between the two bodies-the NCA and the inquiry-is a continuing one and I expect that that useful exchange of information, particularly given the overlapping of the inquiry and the reference being conducted by the NCA, will enable both Mr Fitzgerald and the NCA to better achieve their objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Justice and I take this opportunity to congratulate him on the restitution of his elevated status. As Minister responsible now and in his previous ministry for the Australian Federal Police (AFP), can he tell me whether, in view of the public controversy which developed about the awarding of the coastwatch contract to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, he ever asked for and/or obtained a briefing from the Federal Police on their involvement in the tender process? If so, did that briefing include the fact that in May, as revealed in the documents tabled today by the Minister for Transport and Communications, the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (BCI) said that there was sufficient justification for continuing a probe into Amann Aviation and its associated links? Did any such briefing also reveal that both this conclusion and a BCI report of 30 June were not drawn to the attention of the Department of Transport or Ministers? Did the Minister agree then, and does he agree now, with the decision not to pass on this information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I was aware of the involvement of the Australian Federal Police in the tendering process, mainly because the AFP has the responsibility for the management and co-ordination of the Coastal Protection Unit (CPU) and Chief Superintendent Dixon was a member of the tendering board. So I was aware of all this. In fact, in my first week in office I received fairly continuous daily briefings on the build-up to the Cabinet submission relating to the eventual award of a tender to Amann Aviation. At that time I was briefed by the Australian Federal Police and they certainly did not at any stage indicate anything other than is reflected in annexure 1 to the statement tabled by Senator Gareth Evans this morning-namely, as was recorded in the minute there:

ANSWER.PARA: CPU stated that security checks had been carried out on principals of Amann Aviation through Commonwealth and State police resources. No records existed on any of the principals concerned. Further checks would be conducted through the Corporate Affairs Commission though because of cross indexing between this area and normal police records it was unlikely that anything adverse or of any significance would be found.

Certainly nothing was brought to my attention in that build-up to taking the submission to Cabinet to indicate any concern by the AFP about the suitability of Amann Aviation from the point of view of Amann, his directors, his chief pilot and so on being fit and proper persons. Of course the technical and managerial competence is something for others to assess, not the AFP.

It is quite clear from the documentation-and it is the case-that, when the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence raised the question in late May and suggested that some probe might be undertaken, internal action was taken by various police forces pursuing that query which eventually resulted in the internal minute signed by Mr Dixon of 16 July. Mr Dixon, having followed up all the matters raised by the query from the BCI, came in that internal minute of 16 July 1987, with the concurrence of the BCI, which raised the matter originally, and of Deputy Commissioner Roy Farmer, to the following conclusion, among others:

The matter in issue is the possible embarrassment to the Government if the CVC Directors or corporate associates are disclosed to be of ill repute or with organised crime connotations. This has not been established, nor do I believe on information available to me that an initial suspicion of such connections can be substantiated. Accordingly I am of the view that unless some significant matter can be identified by the BCI as of concern to them or with implications for the Government and/or the civil coastal surveillance system, I see no reason to (a) pursue this probe further or (b) to alert any other persons Department of the initial BCI report.

That judgment was made in the best professional manner by Mr Dixon and was concurred in by the BCI, which raised the matter initially, and by the Deputy Commissioner, Roy Farmer. This led to the fact that I was not informed. As Mr Dixon says, he thought it was not necessary to inform Ministers or departments or other agencies of this conclusion being, as it was, favourable to Amann Aviation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Home Affairs whether his attention has been drawn to comments made in the Senate chamber by Senator MacGibbon yesterday alleging that the Commonwealth electoral boundaries were gerrymandered and, this morning, that those boundaries had been rigged. Are Senator MacGibbon's claims in any way justified and what procedures exist to determine fair electoral boundaries in Commonwealth elections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was present on both occasions when Senator MacGibbon commented on what he regarded as the unfairness of electoral boundaries. Yesterday he said that they were gerrymandered and today I think he used the work `rigged'. It seems to me that some members of the coalition, seeking reasons for their defeat in the last election, may be looking for a scapegoat. They may be looking towards the umpire to fulfil that role. It is very unfair for the Australian Electoral Commission to be isolated for blame for the Liberal failure in the last election. The Australian Electoral Commission's criteria for redistributions emanated from the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform to this chamber and the other House in 1983 and were supported for the most part, with one or two minor exceptions, by every member of this chamber. Indeed, for the first time in Australian history malapportionment and malapportionment provisions were removed from the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Historically, the electoral system nationally has had very little malapportionment, but prior to 1983 it had some entrenched malapportionment.

ANSWER.PARA: All the seats in the 1984 redistribution were allocated above or below a quota depending on their future growth pattern. In my view nothing could be fairer than that. The people who actually distributed the seats were independent commissioners. In the last series of redistributions Professor Colin Hughes, the Chief Electoral Officer for the country, participated in all redistributions. I have never heard his integrity impugned here or anywhere else, yet if accusations are made of gerrymandering they must eventually find their home in Dr Hughes. That is most unfair. Three other commissioners were involved, including the Surveyor-General for every State, the Chief Electoral Officer in each State and, finally, where they were available, the Auditor-General for each State. I ask honour- able senators to note that last point. Previous governments always had the right to appoint one public servant. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform asserted that that could mean that a government could choose someone of its own political persuasion; so we insisted on trying to find the most independent characters around the country to do this process and we fixed on the idea--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha, ha!

—For Senator Walters's benefit I add that it was at the insistence of Sir John Carrick that we fixed on the Auditor-General. I supported Senator Sir John Carrick in that. Indeed, once the boundaries had been set and it went to a rehearing, two additional members were added for those rehearings. They were the Chief Statistician-does anyone here want to impugn his impartiality?-and Justice St John. No one could suggest to me that Justice St John was a party to rigging any electoral boundaries. I believe in the inherent integrity of those commissioners and I believe that most people in this Parliament support me in that. There has been no political interference in the redistribution system in the last few years.

ANSWER.PARA: A further reform brought in is that this chamber and the House of Representatives no longer have the power to reject redistributions. There have been two recent instances of rejection: 1962 saw the Australian Labor Party and the then Australian Country Party gang up against the Liberal Party of Australia and knock over a set of boundaries. In 1975 we saw the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party knock over all boundary changes, all for their political advantage. These days we have removed that power from the hands of the Parliament. Any redistribution proposal is implemented automatically. There are heavy penalties for anyone trying to interfere in the redistribution process. Indeed, we know what happened last time someone tried that. Former Senator Withers-for a very trivial offence in my view-was unfortunately removed from Cabinet and from leadership of the Liberal Party in this chamber. So it ill behoves any member of this chamber, any Minister or anybody else, to try to interfere in that political system.

I assume that what Senator MacGibbon is really saying is that at the last election the Liberal and National parties in total outpolled the Labor Party by 16,000 votes and that therefore the system is not fair. First of all, he overlooks that we have a preferential voting system. If he wants to re-write the rules and say that whoever gets the most votes wins government, could we please have government for 1954, 1961, 1969 and 1980, because we were deprived on those occasions under a first past the post system? In the last election, after distribution of preferences, Labor received 50.8 per cent of the preferred vote and that is why we won the election. People often comment, `Why do you win by such a large margin once you get 50.8 per cent?'. There are two explanations for that. One is the cube rule-that the winner always has a disproportionate majority. The second is that on that occasion the distribution of Labor votes changed from its historical base. The votes are now more evenly spread. We do not lock up massive majorities in the western and northern suburbs and therefore we tend to win marginal seats. We certainly do win marginal seats; I can see four ex-marginal seat holders here who have had to come back to this chamber having lost their marginal seats in the other place.

I just want to say one other thing. I have searched the record and I would be more impressed by Senator MacGibbon's comments if I found him examining and attacking the worst malapportionment and gerrymander that exists in this country-that in the State of Queensland. The Queensland Liberal Party has been a spineless party. It has failed to stand up for its professed principle of equal electorates. It has caved in to the National Party when, in tandem with the Labor Party, it could have forced electoral boundary changes. Indeed, in the last two State elections the Labor Party made this offer to the Liberal Party: Why do you not combine with us and push through fair boundaries? What was the Liberal Party's response? It was to do absolutely nothing.

I state in conclusion that if anyone is wondering why, having held four senators in New South Wales, five in Victoria, five in Western Australia and five in Tasmania and the other States, the Liberal Party has only two senators from Queensland-albeit both long term-in this chamber, it is because of its weak attitude in that State. The reason it has only five out of the 24 House of Representatives seats in Queensland-two of those are highly marginal-is that it has been spineless on this issue of electoral redistribution. I reject the charges made by Senator MacGibbon in the debate yesterday and today. We have some of the fairest electoral boundaries in the world. We are admired by the rest of the world for that. I hope all parties will be committed towards that course.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. If he does, will the Minister exercise his right to disallow this or any other similarly entrepreneurial bid which could open up the lending policies of banks to speculative profit chasing at the expense of ensuring security for Australian depositors? —I was asked whether I had seen a statement by the National Australia Bank Ltd commenting on Mr Spalvins's bid. The answer is no, I have not. —Is the Minister for the Environment and the Arts aware of reports that timber companies in north Queensland have instructed their employees not to supply to the Minister or to their union any information relating to workers who will be affected by world heritage listing of the tropical rainforests? Would the withholding of this information, especially information associated with compensation claims, restrict the ability of the Government to assess the impact on workers of its proposals and to make provision for any compensation that may arise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of allegations of intimidation by, certainly, the Queensland Government and by some Queensland timber companies that have made sure that their workers have been unable to speak to me, under pain of the sack. Only a couple of weeks ago when I was in north Queensland-honour- able senators will remember that I was in north Queensland a few weeks ago--
—Anything for a bit of publicity.

—I can assure Senator Puplick that I am not developing it as a tactic. I was in a hotel in Cairns conducting a number of meetings with interested groups on the issue. At that time I was to meet with a delegation of workers, and I did so. There were about eight or nine of them in attendance. However, I then discovered that three of them had had to go back to work in cars because they had been telephoned when they arrived at the hotel and told that if they spoke to me they would be sacked upon their arrival back at work. During the meeting another two of them were sitting under a tree across the road. I might say that I put a preservation order on that tree to make sure that it is there for next time. What happened was that ordinary workers who wanted to talk to me-not, by the way, to tell me what a great job I was doing, but rather to complain about some aspects of the decisions that the Government has taken and, more importantly, to discuss their future, their prospects of re-employment and what packages might be available to assist them-were prevented from talking to me by the bloody-minded attitude of the Queensland Government and, what is worse, of the timber companies intent on crawling to Bjelke-Petersen and his allies. All I am doing in this exercise is trying to make sure that the 700 people who are affected directly by this decision are given an opportunity at least to hear what plans the Government has for them and for that area. All that will happen is that one area of activity will change and other areas of activity will develop.
—Such as?

—Senator Puplick has had all week to ask a question. If he gets around to it, I will answer it. Other activities will begin which will enable most of these people to be re-employed. More importantly, I hope they will give their families some cause to relax in the future and not to remain with the anguish that they feel now.

ANSWER.PARA: A difficulty will arise if the Queensland Government maintains its attitude. If it threatens the companies who in turn threaten the workers, none of us will get anywhere. At the end of the day this world heritage listing will go through. Over the next couple of months I intend to ensure that those talks do continue and that we can offer most of those workers a future. To those whom we cannot offer jobs, we will offer packages of assistance to help them into other areas. All I require in that endeavour is some co-operation from the Queensland Government. Already we are getting some co-operation. However, it must be remembered that while threats are made to companies, `If you talk to Richardson, we will take away your southern concessions', and while threats are made to the workers, `If you talk to him we'll give you the sack', the reality is that the Premier's Department in Queensland is continuing discussions with my Department. So the Premier has it both ways. What is good enough for him is not good enough for anyone else. However, people in north Queensland are waking up. Members of the industry will be coming to the table next week and the workers will be coming a couple of weeks later. Sooner or later the crack in the dam will widen and breach. In the end the revival of a flagging career of a politician in his death throes is not worth the lives and the futures of Queensland workers, and we are about saving them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is it a fact that the Government expects a 2 1/4 per cent rise in employment and a 3 per cent rise in non-farm gross domestic product during the coming year? Does this not mean a projected rise in national non-farm productivity of less than one per cent? Since national productivity actually fell last year and will rise only minimally in the coming year, how does this square with the 4 per cent wage rise granted this year on the grounds of improved productivity? Is the Government satisfied that the promised improvements in work practices have economically justified the wage rise? Finally, is the Government satisfied that our percentage utilisation of high cost capital equipment is as high as that of our trading competitors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to that question, the first of which relies on assumptions made and figures given in the Budget Papers. I am not in a position, not having the papers in front of me, to disagree with the assumptions; I accept them as being accurate. The most important point of Senator Hamer's question is whether some industries are adequately utilising capital, particularly in terms of working hours. My answer to that question would in general be no.

ANSWER.PARA: But some very significant changes are taking place in some particular industries of which I am aware. For example, the textile and clothing industry awards were varied last year by agreement with the unions, after a lengthy period of discussion, to provide for a much greater spread of hours and continuous shifts in some of the larger plants. In another industry in respect of which negotiations are currently taking place, the number of working days is now, I think it is pretty well agreed, to be increased from something like 218 working days a year to 310. That increase has been negotiated and agreed to. So, in the spirit of Senator Hamer's question, we have some way to go in relation to the utilisation of expensive capital equipment in industry. However, progress is being made in respect of that issue in some industries; in others it is not being made to the extent one would wish.

Senator Hamer asked me in the earlier part of his question whether I was satisfied that the promised improvement in work practices resulting from negotiations, particularly under the second tier, had been achieved. Again, one cannot give a general answer about that matter. My view is that it has been achieved in a number of industries but not in others. The progress of second tier wage negotiations has been very slow for a variety of reasons. Let me give some of the reasons why this has been the case in some industries. Employers say, `We cannot find anything which we want the work force to give up in various issues relating to productivity, hours, et cetera, I find that somewhat strange but that is what they say and that has been a difficulty in the negotiations that have taken place. In some industries the results of those negotiations have been very satisfactory; in others they have not. It is perhaps a bit too early to say in terms of the general picture of work practices. All these things are dependent on fundamental attitudinal changes in industry.

If I might be discursive for one moment, shortly before the recent election I had lunch with a former very prominent employer representative in this country. He said, `The difficulty about this country is that in the 1960s and 1970s employers always argued over a $2 or $3 wage increase and we gave away hours all the time.' Why? Because it did not show up in the books. If a manager of a plant gave a $5 wage increase, the decision would immediately go to the finance director at corporate headquarters, who would say, `What is John Stone or Austin Lewis doing giving a $5 wage increase at that plant?'. If employees at the plant were given a half-hour smoko that decision would not go to the finance director and would not have appeared in the books until now when productivity problems are really becoming more obvious. That is not my view; that was a view put to me and I think a lot of that happened.

The sorts of things about which Senator Hamer has asked me depend fundamentally on achieving attitudinal change in industry at both management and work force levels. There are no magic wands to achieve these things. It is very important that industry, management and the work force keep working at them. There is no arithmetical calculation that one can make to give a conclusion in terms of improvements in work practices or percentage utilisation of capital, for example. However, I am encouraged by the level of progress which is being made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise the Senate of progress in the efforts of an Australian consortium to win a contract for thermal power generation in Turkey?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to advise the Parliament that the Turkish Prime Minister, Mr Turgut Ozal, announced yesterday that a consortium led by the Australian company Seapac Control Services Pty Ltd has been selected to build the first of five planned foreign built thermal power plants in Turkey. This is the first project of its kind to be won by Australia. The project, which is to construct and operate a $1.2 billion, 1,400 megawatt coal fired power station and deep water port, will be located between Botas and Yumurtalik on the northern coast of Iskenderun Bay. Of the final five contenders, the Seapac proposal was judged to be the most competitively priced and was evaluated the best technical and commercial proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: The success of the Seapac proposal guarantees Australian coal exports of 3.9 million tonnes per annum with the possibility of further potential exports of up to 10 million tonnes through the use of port and entrepot facilities. There will also be a significant Australian manufactured content as well as provision of services involved in the project.

Finally, while the Queensland Government has shown its support for the project by its equity participation in the consortium, it is, I think, fair to emphasise the role that the Australian Government, through the Prime Minister, other relevant Ministers and the Ambassador in Ankara, has played consistently in lending support to the Seapac consortium in this proposal.

—I thank the honourable senator for his question. I am aware of a number of things about the wet tropics.
—Just answer the question. That is all we want.
—Order, Senator Boswell!

—Mr President, as I was saying before being rudely interrupted, I am aware of a number of things about the wet tropics and north Queensland rainforests.
