—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and follows on from a question which I think was asked by Senator Stone yesterday and the sham or shadow Budget put down last night by Mr Howard. Is the Minister aware that Mr Howard and other Opposition spokespeople have accused the Government of complacency in responding to Australia's current account deficit problem? Can the Minister give an assurance that these criticisms are unfounded and explain the Government's policy position in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am broadly aware of the remarkable statements that were made by Mr Howard last night. The most relevant facts are these: In 1985-86, as a consequence of the collapse in the prices of Australian export commodities, the current account deficit moved up to 6 per cent of gross domestic product. In 1986-87, as a result of the effects of the devaluation and the success of the Government's economic policies, the current account deficit fell to 5.1 per cent of gross domestic product. We expect it to fall to 4 per cent in this financial year. Four per cent, of course, is still too high a figure for any sensible person to be completely satisfied with, but we expect it to fall further in the following year. There is no complacency on the part of the Government in regard to the current account deficit problem.

ANSWER.PARA: That is in marked contrast to the position which Mr Howard took when he was Treasurer. In 1981-82, Australia recorded a current account deficit-on the basis of the then available gross domestic product statistics, that is, those available early in the 1982-83 financial year-of 6 1/4 per cent of gross domestic product, well above the figure forecast in the August 1981 Budget which, incidentally, was slightly greater than 4 1/4 per cent of gross domestic product. That slightly greater figure, 12 months later, had grown to become 50 per cent greater.

Was the then Treasurer or, so far as we can tell from the public record, the then Treasury Secretary, galvanised into action by that deficit, by a recorded current account deficit of 6 1/4 per cent of gross domestic product? Not a bit of it. The 1982 Budget Statement No. 2 forecast a 1982-83 current account deficit `broadly similar' to the 1981-82 figure and expressed absolutely no concern about it. In other words, at the time that forecast was made the best available evidence showed that the deficit for the previous year had been 6 1/4 per cent-the highest on record-and that it would be broadly similar in the following year. That, according to the judgment of the Public Service officer and the Treasurer most responsible at that time, was nothing to be worried about at all. Mr Howard's 1982 Budget Speech stated:
After taking account of some increase in the invisibles deficit, the current account deficit may be broadly similar to that in 1981-82.

That is, 6 1/4 per cent, from the best information that was available at the time. I should also quote from Budget Statement No. 2 because it is generally regarded-I do not know whether it is entirely correct to regard it as such-as expressing the view of the Treasury rather than the Treasurer or the government of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —No longer.
—Senator Stone would certainly know something about 1981 and 1982. If the quotation does not express his view he can let us know at some time. Budget Statement No. 2 said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the outlook for exports and imports of goods and services and a likely increase in the net invisibles deficit, including strong growth in interest payments abroad, would suggest a current account deficit in 1982-83 broadly similar to that in 1981-82.

So the Treasurer's Budget Speech and Budget Statement No. 2 both forecast a deficit broadly similar to that which had been recorded in the previous year, which was the highest current account deficit since records have been kept, if not forever. They expected it to flow on to the next financial year and expressed absolutely no alarm about it.

It has been said from time to time that there was less reason to be concerned about the current account deficit in the early 1980s because the deficit at that time was driven by the import of capital equipment associated with the resources boom, which in the end never happened, which would earn the foreign exchange which would comfortably service the overseas debt obligations which were being incurred and so on. The catch is that it is not true. For the years 1980-81 and 1981-82 the capital goods imports accounted for 24.6 per cent of total imports. The average for 1985-86 and 1986-87 was 25.3 per cent. In other words, the ratio of capital goods imports to total imports in the last two years was higher than it was in the early 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. It concerns the Government's intention to provide grants for only 3,500 to 4,000 additional higher education places for school leavers next year and to reduce the intake of part time and mature age students. How exactly will the balance of the announced 5,800 new places be financed? Will there not be an overall reduction in the number of higher education students in Australia, that is, an overall decrease in participation? Given that a part time mature age student incurs fewer costs than a full time student-even a school leaver-precisely how many mature age and part time student places does the Government expect will be lost in higher education institutions next year as a result of the Budget measure? Exactly what process will apply to determine how many part time and mature age places will be lost at each university, college and institute of technology? Finally, does the Minister agree that the Budget measures relating to new student enrolments create an even greater burden of Commonwealth Government interference in the way universities and colleges conduct their affairs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not agree with the last part of Senator Teague's very longwinded question, but I will provide him with the information I have available to me about those parts of his question that go to the growth in participation in higher education which will come about as a result of the Budget decisions. I emphasise that we are continuing our record of growth in higher education. Any suggestion, such as was contained in Senator Teague's question, that there will be a natural reduction in intake is quite wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: The total number of higher education places in 1988 will be around 310,600, which is a record number. The total increase in Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) funded places between 1983 and 1988 will be around 38,700. In addition, by 1988 a further 15,500 places will be funded from other sources. An additional 5,800 higher education intakes will be made available for young school leavers in 1988. Of those intakes, 3,500 to 4,000 will be funded by the Government, and CTEC will advise on means by which the further 2,000 intakes of school leavers can be achieved. The remaining places may be found by institutions readjusting the composition of intakes further in favour of young school leavers. This may mean more mature age entrants taking up part time and external places.

Emphasis in allocating new places will be on courses relevant to economic requirements, including 650 new places to computer science, electronics, engineering and other information industries disciplines. Of these, 200 places will be devoted to pilot information technology courses being developed with industry. The remainder of the places will be concentrated in science, technology, design, economics and commerce. I add-and perhaps Senator Teague will be interested in this-that 200 of the new intakes will further increase the participation of Aboriginals.

I think those figures demonstrate continued growth and expansion in higher education places, which has been characteristic of our Government since it was first elected. There will be a continuing and, indeed, increased emphasis on growth in areas relevant to economic needs and, of course, in my reference to the increased Aboriginal places, an ongoing concern for equity and participation in access to higher education places.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Further to the Minister's answer, to what precisely does she refer when she says that some of the places will be funded from other sources? By admitting that the 2,000 places that are in discrepancies are being referred to CTEC to advise on how they will be funded, can she say what the guidelines are for CTEC and when that knowledge or report will be received by the Government?

—The Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, will be making a full statement on the Government's intentions for higher education. The question asked by Senator Teague was about a further reference to CTEC for places to be funded by other than Commonwealth sources, which could include places funded by the private sector. I have referred to the 200 pilot places in information technology courses which are being funded by the private sector, including IBM Australia Ltd. I think there are other companies involved but I am familiar particularly with IBM's involvement. There is a capacity for the private sector to move in here and assist the universities and colleges to develop new courses. I expect that when Mr Dawkins sets out his statement he will explain this process in detail.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Local Government. Given my understanding of the role played by local government and its need to attract every dollar and make those dollars go further, has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recent statement by the Queensland Premier to the annual conference of the Queensland Local Government Association that the Queensland Government will no longer activate the Local Government Grants Commission? What effect would the Queensland Government's refusal to use the Grants Commission have on the 134 Queensland local government authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Burns raises a very concerning matter. I am aware that the Premier has threatened the future of the Queensland Local Government Grants Commission. This is extremely concerning not just for me as the Minister responsible for local government funding, but also for local government throughout Queensland. Should the Queensland Premier pursue his threats-and I believe that the Queensland Premier is only grandstanding in his usual style-the effect on local government authorities in Queensland would be absolutely disastrous. The Commonwealth Act under which general purpose financial assistance to local government is provided requires that, before a State is entitled to a payment under the Act, it must have a local government grants commission. Each State must have a local government grants commission or it cannot receive funding to pass on to local government. Therefore, were Queensland to refuse to activate its Grants Commission, it would not be able to receive its entitlement under the Act. In other words local government authorities in Queensland would no longer receive these grants. Given that this year the amount is in the order of $106m, that would be an absolute disaster for Queensland local government.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that, unfortunately, rather than taking a more conciliatory role, the Deputy Premier, Mr Gunn, has also made a similar threat. In a report in the Daily Sun on the 15th of this month, he foreshadowed the demise of the Grants Commission. Again, I call on both the Premier of Queensland and the Deputy Premier to adopt a less confrontationist role with the Commonwealth Government and start to talk about the way in which funding principles should be established for next year so that we do not have the kinds of arrangements and hostility that we have had this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Deputy Leader of the Government in this place in his ministerial capacity and follows earlier questioning on the Amann matter. I ask the Minister about a response which was given by Mr Duncan in the House of Representatives a little while ago to a question which followed Mr Duncan having advised the House that he had relied on an oral briefing which he had received from his colleague Senator Evans. He was asked whether he was then saying that the sole basis of his answer yesterday was not, in fact, documents but an oral briefing from Senator Evans; if in fact he was relying on documents in the answer that he gave yesterday, whether he could now tell the House whether the document, or those documents, was one of those referred to in the documents tabled in the House this morning; and, if not, whether there was any other document on which he was relying in giving his answer. Mr Duncan replied:

QUESTION.PARA: The reference yesterday to documents referred to documents which were part of the tender process, not the latter documents which were tabled in the House this morning.

I ask: Are there, in fact, any minutes from the police relating not to what has already been tabled but to the tendering process which would explain Mr Duncan's answer? If there is such a document, will the Minister please table it? If there is not, will he seek clarification from his colleague as to what was intended?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be that I will need to seek some clarification because I am not willing to rely on Senator Chaney's account of what transpired in the other place, nor on summary notes and things that have been passed to me. Obviously, it depends on what Mr Duncan actually said and obviously I will find out what he did say precisely in due course. The situation so far as documents are concerned is that all relevant documents in my Department or those that were involved in the tendering process or in any subsequent police activity after that tendering process-certainly all the ones that I am aware of-were referred to in the statement that I made this morning or were attached to that statement, as the case may be. There are no other documents that I am aware of that bear upon this particular question.

ANSWER.PARA: My discussions with my colleague about this matter were very brief over the course of the last six weeks-understandably so, since we were both extremely preoccupied with our respective areas of responsibility in our new portfolio-and it was only simply a matter from time to time of keeping up to date with developments on matters of current moment. My recollection, like that of my colleague, is that we really discussed the security dimensions of this, I think, probably on only one occasion. That was, as I recall, only some two weeks ago, around the time-maybe just before or just after-I was in physical possession of the materials supplied to me by Mr Beale. In this place, in this job, two weeks sometimes feels like two months, so I cannot be very precise about the dates in question. As I recall it, there was only one such conversation that bore upon the security matters.

My own recollection of that conversation is saying that there was some police material that had been brought to my attention or was in the process of being brought to my attention-I am not sure which. I recall saying to him something like, `I don't think there is anything in it, but I haven't had time to go through that material yet'. It is clearly that particular conversation that has stuck in Mr Duncan's memory and was the basis of his response yesterday, rather than sighting by him of any material that could possibly bear upon this particular question.

A mistake was made yesterday. But, as the Prime Minister has described it, it was a completely honest mistake and a perfectly understandable one in the circumstances. The documents that were tabled this morning and the statement that was made this morning are a full and comprehensive account of this particular matter. I have offered to the Opposition the opportunity to be briefed by the senior police officers concerned. As I walked in for Question Time I asked whether any communication had been made by anyone in the Opposition to take up that particular offer. The answer was in the negative. If the Opposition were to pursue this matter any further in the absence of taking advantage of that offer, I would only describe their actions as being carried out in the utmost bad faith.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. To avoid any further misunderstandings or mistakes, can the Minister clarify which of the answers he has just given is the one he intended? He has said twice that there is no further minute from the police relating to the tender process, and he has said on the other hand that there is no minute of which he is aware. Which of those versions is the answer that he wishes us to regard as the answer we should rely on? Is there no minute, or is he saying that as far as he knows there is no minute but that he will check again and find out?

—I am endowed with some metaphysical properties, I suppose-we all are-but one of them is not a capacity to testify confidently about matters of which I am not aware. The most I can say is that I was speaking yesterday and today-and will again in the future-on the basis of all the information which is available to me about documents which exist and which either have been previously brought to the attention of me or my Department or remain in departmental files. There are some documents that do undoubtedly exist in police files, I suppose-reports of earlier investigations which were the subject of oral reports and which are not in departmental files. There is no doubt some material of that kind. But the documents of which I am speaking are those of which I am aware. I believe my understanding of the situation is complete in this respect on the basis of the very detailed discussions that have been held between my senior officer Mr Beale-he is no relation, and he certainly would not claim to be one, to the Opposition's Mr Beale-and the senior police officers concerned. So I am not going on a hunt for documents which are reminiscent of the mythical snark. I do not believe they exist.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent to the following Bills reported:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) has provided the following answer to Senator McLean's supplementary question. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon suspension of the sitting I was making the point that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in effect claim that the forthcoming joint sitting of the Commonwealth Parliament following the double dissolution is somehow a government sleight of hand, a conjurer's trick. The Liberals and the Nationals already have a track record of constitutional vandalism in Australia, and it now appears that the Democrats are heading down that particular path. That is most regrettable.

SPEECH.PARA: The logic of the present situation is clear: the 11 July election was called because the Senate, this chamber, refused to pass the Australia Card legislation. Honourable senators opposite are trying to create the fiction that the election was not fought on the issue of the Australia Card, that it was not mentioned in the election campaign. I simply invite members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to read page 3026 of Hansard for 27 May when it was made very clear by the Leader of the Government in this place, Senator Button, that the Australia Card was the reason that the double dissolution had been called requiring the people to go to the polls on 11 July. It is a fiction, therefore, for honourable senators opposite to claim that the Australia Card was not raised in the context of the election, because in the Hansard record of the proceedings both of this place and of the other place it is very clear indeed that the Australia Card was at the centre of the issues leading to the 1987 general election.

The Government fought the election on the Australia Card as well as on other issues such as taxation and the state of the economy. Of course, it is now a matter of historical record that we won government, and won handsomely. The conclusion is obvious: the Government has a mandate to proceed to a joint sitting of Parliament to resolve the deadlock over the Australia Card. It is a matter of great regret to me that the opposition to this measure-comprising Liberal, National and Australian Democrat members-will not accept the umpire's decision. It is as clear as that: they went to the election, they lost, and they will not accept the umpire's decision on the Australia Card. On 11 July the Australian people had their opportunity to decide the future of the Australia Card and of the Government of Australia. The Australian people made their decision. They re-elected the Hawke Government for a third successive term. In doing so the Australian people gave the Government a green light to proceed with the Australia Card.

My awareness of proposals to introduce an identity card goes back several years; in fact, to conventions and annual conferences of the Australian Labor Party in South Australia. It is there, I believe, that the origins of the Australia Card can in fact be found. I well recall a motion moved by delegates from the Kilburn sub-branch-which is situated in a working class district in the northern suburbs of Adelaide-earlier this decade calling for some sort of identification system. Those working class people, those employed members of the community, well understood that tax evasion and avoidance was rampant and rife in the Australian community and they saw a need to do something about it. So, with the very good sense of the working class of this country, they proceeded to the State conference of the Labor Party and proposed that we adopt an identification system to clamp down on tax cheating and welfare cheating in Australia. That is what the Australia Card is directed at-tax evasion and welfare fraud-because the use of false identities is a major contributor to tax evasion. False identities and the misstatement of personal financial circumstances are also a major factor behind social welfare fraud. I believe the Australia Card will provide a unique identifier of the highest integrity for each individual.

The card will help combat tax evasion and welfare fraud by determining eligibility for social security benefits and for a wide range of financial transactions. It will also enable the Australian Taxation Office to draw together financial information about individuals to ensure that correct taxation assessments occur. The card will also prevent people from double dipping, as it is called, from the Department of Social Security and obtaining benefits under false identities or where their financial circumstances should preclude them from doing so.

The Australia Card will contain a person's name, signature, special identification number, the period of the card's validity and a photograph. All Australian citizens will be eligible to register for the card. I must stress that it will not be compulsory to carry the card. The legislation is very clear on that. Nor will it be used as a means of general identification or as an internal passport. During the last session of Parliament I heard Senator Peter Baume, one of the more liberal of the Opposition senators, claiming that this identification system would result in it being an internal passport. I was most disappointed to hear somebody of the calibre of Senator Baume making such outrageous claims in the Senate.

After hearing that I took the opportunity to telephone the Australian Federal Police to find out just how many Australian Federal Police officers there are in South Australia, because the legislation makes it very clear that the only police authorities who will be able to examine breaches of the card will be the Federal Police. I found out that in the whole of South Australia, which has a population approaching 1,400,000, we have a total Federal Police establishment of 99 men and women to check breaches of the card. It can hardly be argued that it will be an internal passport. Even though the legislation makes it very clear that it will not be, honourable senators opposite still go around the country claiming that it will be. But I repeat that in my State there are only 99 Federal policemen who can actually ask to see the card.

The Australia Card Register will contain only personal identifying data, such as a person's name, residential address and postal address, date of birth, sex, a digitised photo and a signature and, of course, verifying information used to establish identity. Contrary to the claims made opposite, the Register will not be a comprehensive central database and will not contain information about a person's marital status, family composition, religion, employment, political affiliation, medical history or banking and taxation records. The information contained on the Register will be confined to basic identification data already existing-I repeat, `data already existing'-for the legitimate purpose of Government departments in this country. Much of this existing data we have found from research contains duplications and inaccuracies which will be resolved by the Australia Card. That is one of the things that those opposite do not mention, that the current information which is available in many cases is very inaccurate. We know this from samples that have been taken. This initiative will enable a clearing up of that inaccurate information.

There will be strictly limited access to the information in the Australia Card Register. Only officials from the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security and the Health Insurance Commission will have access to the Register for tax linkage purposes and, of course, for establishing identification for welfare payment purposes. Access to the information on the Register will need to be specifically authorised and the authorisation approved by the Data Protection Agency. That Agency is a new watchdog body that we are establishing under the legislation to protect the rights of privacy of individuals by controlling the collection and use of personal data for the Australia Card. The Government believes that by making the production of the Australia Card mandatory for a number of specific uses, it will be possible to achieve substantial revenue gains, reductions in tax evasion and greater equity and fairness between members of the community in contributing towards the costs of providing government services and in the distribution of government welfare assistance. It will also provide a convenient high level integrity means of identification without adversely affecting honest individuals.

The legislation also sets out the specific uses to which the card may be put, including the opening of an account with a bank or a building society, the purchase of stocks and shares and so on. Those uses are specifically listed in the legislation and the production of the card is mandatory only for those uses. It will not be compulsory for any other use. In fact, it will be an offence for the card to be requested by private sector bodies, by State government and local government bodies and by State law enforcement agencies. I emphasise the point I made earlier, that in my State only 99 Federal Police officers will be able to request to see the card while between 3,000 and 4,000 State police men and women will not be able to request to see it. I think that really does nail the lie about compulsory carriage and about the card being used as an internal passport.

I believe that major benefits will be obtained from the Australia Card. There will be increased taxation revenue arising from a reduced incidence of tax evasion. The Government's estimates are that the card will cost some $55m a year to operate-that is on the costings done in the last parliamentary session-but will provide total savings of some $900m a year. The savings far exceed the costs, on the estimates, and between $3 and $4 will be recouped for every one dollar spent setting up the system. There are a number of safeguards in the legislation and associated with it. The legislation includes measures to protect the rights of privacy of individuals and to prevent abuses of the card. It specifies all the permitted uses of the card-the number and the Australia Card Register-and all unauthorised uses which are specifically prohibited. As I have pointed out before, the Australia Card legislation establishes the Data Protection Agency. So there are a number of protections and safeguards included in the legislation.

Honest and hardworking Australians-the great majority of our community-know that they have absolutely nothing to fear from the implementation of the Australia Card system. Honest and hardworking Australians are sick and tired of paying through the nose to subsidise tax evaders and welfare cheats. They want action to stamp out tax evasion and welfare fraud. By voting against the Australia Card proposal, the coalition parties and the Australian Democrats are delaying the Government in acting against tax evaders and welfare cheats. They are prepared to allow the tax system and the social security system to be ripped off to the tune of $1,000m every year. The Liberals and the Nationals are trying to eke out every ounce of political milage from the Australia Card issue. For the sake of short term political gain they are prepared to let honest and hard working Australians subsidise the criminal activities of tax evaders and welfare cheats.

Earlier comments made by Opposition members in support of the Australia Card concept exposed the Opposition's manifest hypocrisy on this issue. Mr Ray Braithwaite, a member of the National Party of Australia in the Federal Parliament and the then shadow Minister for Social Security, was quoted in the Brisbane Courier Mail on 16 May 1985, as follows:
What we need in Australia to effectively fight all forms of abuse is a proper identification of each Australian with a number, photograph and even a fingerprint.

Even a fingerprint! Mr Ray Braithwaite was calling for an identification system involving the use of a fingerprint. Mr Ralph Hunt, the then Deputy Leader of the National Party, in a Press release dated 5 June 1985, stated:

The use of plastic cards for an effective means of identification would streamline the collection of tax revenue, imposing a greater accountability on that small minority of taxpayers who sought to evade their responsibilities to the community.
Further, Mr Charles Blunt, another member of the National Party and currently a frontbencher, in a media release dated 8 June 1985, said:
The introduction of a national identification system using identification cards, offered benefits to the Australian people which outweighed any civil liberties considerations.
He went on to say:
With the Government's White Paper on tax reform recommending the introduction of identification cards, there is now broad bi-partisan support for this measure. It should therefore be implemented.

Mr Acting Deputy President, when I last spoke in this chamber on this subject I referred to a colleague of yours, Mr Trevor Griffin. Mr Trevor Griffin, who is the Liberal shadow Attorney-General in South Australia, was quoted on 13 November last in the Adelaide Advertiser as saying that ID cards with a photograph should be introduced as a means of preventing under-age drinking. The attitude of the South Australian branch of the Liberal Party was that identification cards should be introduced to stop young people consuming alcohol. On the other hand, the Liberal Party does not want to see an identification card system introduced to crack down on tax cheating and welfare cheating. Of course, Mr Trevor Griffin is a very close and intimate political colleague of Senator Messner and Senator Vanstone in this place.

Once again the Australian Democrats are threatening to vote against legislation aimed at stamping out tax evasion in this country. They are threatening to do that at a time when they go around Australia calling on the Government to increase expenditure or calling for proposals which will diminish the Government's revenue. I well remember that in 1983 three members of the Australian Democrats, including Senator Macklin and Senator Haines, who are still members of this chamber, voted to block the Hawke Government's bottom of the harbour tax evasion legislation. I remember that well because the sum of money involved was stupendous. It was not $5m or $57m. Those honourable senators voted to block legislation which was designed to recoup $570m from tax cheats in this country. That figure pales into insignificance compared with the $1,000m a year that will be lost if the Australia Card legislation is blocked in the Senate. One can come to the conclusion that, as a result of the revenue involved, those Democrat senators are very expensive and very costly members of this place. They are a very high price for the majority of Australia's taxpayers to pay.

The Democrats claim that the Government did not make the Australia Card an issue during the election campaign. They have been saying ever since 12 July that we did not make it an issue. How does Senator Haines explain the fact that the very first Labor Party advertisement in the national Press was in fact on the Australia Card issue? The very first election advertisement that we inserted during the campaign was on the Australia Card issue. How does Senator Haines explain to the Australian people the fact that the Democrats are making more noise about the Australia Card after the election than during the campaign itself? When the Democrats got the double dissolution that they desperately wanted, any Democrat noise about the Australia Card was far outweighed by the sound of the popping of champagne corks in Senator Haines's office. That is the reality. There was absolutely no suggestion from the Democrats during the second debate on the Australia Card in April this year that there should be another Senate inquiry into the Australia Card. That is a fact. In April this year there was absolutely no suggestion that there should be another inquiry into the Australia Card. The Democrats leapt at the opportunity for a double dissolution to save their own political skins. They knew that the double dissolution would result in a reduction in the electoral quotas from 14.3 to 7.7 per cent of the vote. They knew that a double dissolution offered a real chance for them to get back into business. That is what they were mainly interested in. That is why they consumed champagne when the Leader of the Government in this place, Senator Button, pointed out that an election was going to be fought as a result of the Australia Card being blocked in this place. The Australia Card clearly was the issue which triggered the July election. As a result of that election, Labor received a clear majority of the two-party preferred vote throughout Australia. The Democrats are simply thumbing their noses at the Australian Constitution and the Australian people.

Some people go around the place saying that what we need is a tax file number system. If the community is serious about stamping out tax evasion and welfare fraud, the Australia Card must be implemented. There are no practical alternatives which offer the same level of integrity or cost efficiency. The tax file number alternative has been rejected on the following grounds: it is a low integrity system which opens up the potential for impersonation and it would entrench long standing false identifies because, regrettably, it appears that there are many false identities within the tax file system in Australia. They are some of the disadvantages of the alternative proposals being put forward by Opposition and Democrat spokespersons in this place.

Tax evasion has reached such levels in Australia as to pose severe financial constraints on Government spending programs. Even without Liberal, National and Democrat calls for more spending by government or more cuts in government revenues, we have now reached a situation where, as a result of tax evasion, we face very severe financial constraints. We cannot tolerate a situation where the Government is losing billions of dollars every year through tax evasion. Unfortunately, tax evasion has become entrenched in the psyche of significant sections of the Australian community. It is clear that tax evaders will not be deterred by exhortation alone. Practical measures such as the Australia Card are essential if all Australians are to pay their fair share of tax.

The Government has a mandate to proceed with the Australia Card. The 11 July election was called by the Government because of the Senate's refusal to pass the card legislation. I repeat that the Hawke Government went to the people on the issue of the Australia Card. That was made clear here and in the House of Representatives on 27 May. The electorate responded by voting for the Hawke Government and it gave it a majority of the two-party preferred vote. Parliamentary democracy has always relied on an element of voluntary compliance with accepted conventions-that is the reality-the most important of those conventions being that the people's representatives should abide by the wishes of the electorate at the ballot box. Opposition and Democrat senators should pause to reflect on this before they dig around the foundations of democracy in this country. There are bigger threats to personal rights and liberties from digging at the foundations of democracy than from the present subject of their bleatings-the Australia Card.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with those who suggested earlier in the day that we are discussing probably one of the most profound issues to come before an Australian parliament since Federation. My feelings about this issue have changed quite significantly in the last few months as, obviously, have those of the Australian community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: Only three or four months ago during the process of pre-selection within my own Party I was posed the question, `What is your attitude towards the Australia Card?' In the rounds my reaction at that time was that it was much ado about nothing. Because I had in fact carried an ID card for most of my life and I had a whole series of numbers, for a while I saw this issue as being of limited significance. However, somebody said to me that surely, by that logic, I would have no objections to somebody tapping my telephone or opening my mail. All of a sudden I started to think more seriously about the significance of what was being proposed. It was put to me, and it came home to me, that this issue is about the most fundamental plank of freedom, privacy. One cannot compromise privacy. There are not many issues in life which are black and white, but privacy is one of them, and that is fundamental to this proposal for an Australia Card.

In this debate it is important for us to distinguish between the card-an inoffensive thing that we carry in our pockets and which is an instrument of convenience for many of us and for systems at large-and the register as such, the database, the dimension of this whole process which is beginning to attract particular attention. Theoretically, we have been subjected to the facts in previous presentations here today.

We are supposed to have heard the facts about the costs and benefits of this issue, but I suggest that nobody knows the facts. What we are hearing is a mass of speculation. It may prove to be as inaccurate as the projections of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on revenue from the fringe benefits tax. He was 900 per cent wrong in that respect. It may well be that he is 900 per cent wrong on the negative side of the equation in the supposed facts that we have before us on the Australia Card. We do not have any facts; we have a whole mass of projections and speculation.

I believe that there is a great deal of room in this debate for feeling. For some reason or other we in this country believe that we have to be objective about everything, yet many of the things we do in life are quite subjective. Most of us choose our life partners, our friends, our associates by subjective criteria. What we feel in our guts and in our hearts is significant to us. I project that the Australian population does not believe there are any facts because they heard about temporary income tax in 1940; they heard about the fact that TAB offices were to be highly protected places, but now find them in community recreation centres. They have no confidence in governments to protect them, so they are now reacting with their gut and heart.

We are told that this issue is about recouping dollars and cents. It almost made me ill to see the Treasurer responding to questions at the National Press Club the other evening and quantifying the dimensions of this proposal in terms of recouped dollars and cents, without a single reference to the fundamental issues of privacy, liberty and freedom. This is all about choice. The fundamental question posed here is: do we wish to be pushed, ever so coaxingly, across a significant line? It is the line between an essentially libertarian society and an essentially authoritarian society. The Bill mentions `the Authority' and `the authorities' over and over again. It is a document about authoritarianism. If we proceed with this legislation what we will be doing quite deliberately, at the suggestion of this Government, is passing across that significant line between an essentially free, libertarian society and one which will become increasingly authoritarian.

The fundamental issue here is one of gut and heart. It is about liberty, choice and having all the facts. It is about being able to weigh and deliberate over those facts. It is about being able to decide whether we want to be fundamentally a libertarian or an authoritarian society. Probably we come back to the question whether the Australian people should be consulted, whether the Australian people should be fully informed. I am thankful that they are becoming fully informed. By the processes that we are ensuring in this chamber every day they are becoming increasingly informed. I do not know whether honourable senators are aware of the fact that just a few hours ago 5,000 people turned out at a public rally in Adelaide on this issue. I attended and spoke to a public rally in Hobart several weeks ago, the biggest rally held in Tasmania since the Franklin Dam issue.

Fundamental to this whole process is the distinction between the issue of the card and the issue of the databank. I wish to pose four fundamental objections to the propositions inherent in this Bill. My first objection is that it would seem to me that the whole proposition of having an Australia Card is totally unnecessary. Let me deal with the question of first basic proof. Presumably, if we proceed with this farce, eventually the vast majority of Australians will be called upon to make the first fundamental proof of identity to someone somehow. It seems to me logical that if we are able to do that and if we accept the proposition, which has been advanced time and again from the Government in this place and in public forums, that the requirement to use this card to prove identity will be very rare and will occur on very few occasions and if there is in existence an instrument that is sufficiently reliable to prove initially our identity, that that same instrument should suffice on these relatively few occasions that we are told we will be called upon. In other words, there is a first fundamental logical flaw in the argument.

We are told and we read over and over again in reports by the Auditor-General-and we have been reading this for 20 years-that there is a tax and welfare rip-off. We have even been told the solutions to these problems. We have even been told that the legislation has to be strengthened and we have been told the potential returns from strengthening it. Therefore, we are not being told anything new. We all surely agree that the tax rorts and welfare rip-offs have to be stopped. The answer obviously lies in strengthening the legislation which is directly relevant to the area of fraud or abuse. My first point is that the whole exercise is totally and utterly unnecessary, and it is known to be unnecessary by those who are proposing it.

The second point is that essentially it is a dangerous proposition. I have already hinted that it will translate us from where we are now to a different social situation. Australians, once they understand the implications, are now saying that it is totally unacceptable. It is dangerous because it will render us an authoritarian society. Do Australians really want to take their place with societies such as South Africa, Chile or the majority in the Eastern European bloc? Is there any need for us to go there? I do not believe there is. It is an un-Australian place to go. It is dangerous because it asks us to invert the basic fundamental assumption of our society. We can assume and have assumed in Australian society for a long time that the vast majority of people are honest. This fundamental proposition contained in the Bill will invert that proposition and lead one to assume that the vast majority of Australians are dishonest. For 50 years I have been able to put out my hand and say `G'day, I'm Paul McLean'. The majority of people have accepted and believed me. Why should I be asked today, immediately from now, all of a sudden to prove it? I do not believe that that is necessary. I believe that it is offensive, and I believe that is what fundamentally the vast majority of Australians find offensive and dangerous about this proposition-its authoritarian dimension.

My third objection hinges on the question of honesty versus dishonesty. Senator Maguire has just assured us that the double dissolution was fundamentally a process of honesty, that the Australian population knew what it was all about, and that they are informed about double dissolutions and joint sittings. I do not believe it. We can only speculate on the arguments that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) must have advanced to the Governor-General at the time the Governor-General approved a double dissolution of both Houses of the national Parliament. It would have been essential that the Prime Minister would have said: `Sir, this is a matter of the most profound national importance. This proposition for an ID card is fundamental to my Government proceeding. In fact, it is one of the most fundamental and profound issues ever to face the nation'. He must have marshalled the arguments very convincingly, because he was back very quickly. I was here as a visitor to the chamber that day and heard simultaneously the announcement that our Parliament had been dissolved prematurely, unnecessarily, farcically and that he had to go to the people on this proposition of the Australia Card, on the issue of freedom and choice. But we did not hear a word about it. Presumably the same arguments that were put to the Governor-General for a double dissolution were not advanced out of any sense of honesty or honour by the Prime Minister or, for that matter, by any of those who were representing him in the campaign process. They were not advanced to the Australian people. Not once did the Prime Minister refer to this in his fundamental primary statement to the nation. Not once do I recall him actually initiating reference to it, but only responding to questions. In fact, the Australian people were deceived about the real issue of that election. I believe that the whole process of arriving at that double dissolution was the greatest confidence trick that Australians have ever been subjected to. And, by heavens, there have been some confidence tricks in our history! But this was the greatest.

Let me turn to a second dimension of dishonesty. I believe that the Bill is inherently dishonest. If we read it and really understand it-it is difficult to understand and there is no way in which the Australian people could understand it without its being explained by concerned Australian citizens-we find that the Bill suggests that Australians really have a choice as to whether they become card carriers. The expression used is that the Australian people will be `invited to apply for an identification card'. What a delightful phrase to use! They will be `invited to apply' for a card. When one looks at this farce, this pretence of choice, one finds the implications of exercising what appears to be one of two choices. Let us imagine that somebody courteously refuses this invitation to apply for an ID card and chooses to become a non-card carrier in our free society. Such people will live with horrendous implications. Their right to work, to property and to their own assets which have been accumulated by hard work, and a whole series of fundamental rights, will in fact be denied them.

The Bill is even more dishonest than that. It does not direct abuse at those people specifically. There is no obligation to apply for this card; the penalty is directed at that person's bank manager, employer or someone else who is absolutely vital to his or her commercial and other life processes. If an employer does not ask a person to produce the card or is not satisfied that that person can produce it that employer faces a $20,000 fine. If a bank manager does not ask for the card or does not freeze a non-cardholder's assets, he faces a $20,000 fine. We are told that under this Bill we have a choice, but there is no choice there. This is the most offensive proposition that has ever been put before the Australian people.

I wish to explore the possibility of those on this side of the chamber, who oppose this Bill, actually not becoming card carriers. Do honourable senators know who is supposed to be fined $20,000 in this case? Do they know who is supposed to ask us as senators for this card? Our employer. Who is our employer? The Australian people. I believe that I have been elected on the mandate of opposing this card. Yet it is implied in this Bill that the Australian people are supposed, first of all, to ask me for my card and then, if I do not produce it, they are supposed to be fined $20,000. Presumably that will apply to more than 50 per cent of senators in this chamber if present indications are true. I was formerly a schoolteacher. Had somebody put this document in front of me I would have said, `Look, you have not done your homework; take it back and rethink it. It is shallow, it is empty.' That is exactly what the Australian people should do to this piece of potential legislation.
